In modern language, someone who tends not to wear shoes in public or is participating in the aforementioned sports may be described as a '''barefooter'''.{{cite book|title=Barefoot water skiing: an illustrated guide to learning and mastering the sport|year=1988|publisher=World Publications, Incorporated|page=161|url=https://books.google.com/?id=6I2WE5XWIQ8C&q=barefooter&dq=barefooter|author1=Scarpa, R |author2=Dorner, T. |isbn=978-0-944406-01-4}}{{cite book|last=Wallack|first=R.M.|title=Run for Life: The Anti-Aging, Anti-Injury, Super-Fitness Plan to Keep You Running to 100|year=2009|publisher=Sky Horse Publishing|isbn=978-1-60239-344-8|page=34|url=https://books.google.com/?id=pkjcENkpO6cC&pg=PA34&dq=barefooter#v=onepage&q=barefooter&f=false}} [[File:Hans Thoma - Kinderreigen (1872).jpg | thumb|Children Dancing in a Ring - 1872]] ==Historical and religious aspects== {{see also|Footwear}} [[File:Discobolus in National Roman Museum Palazzo Massimo alle Terme.JPG|thumb|upright|Ancient Olympic [[discus]] thrower]] [[File:Prisoner in courtroom, Wales 19th century.JPG|thumb|upright|Barefooted female prisoner;
[[Wales]], 19th century (museum exhibit)]] People in ancient times, such as the [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptians]], [[Hindu]]s, and [[Ancient Greece|Greeks]] often went barefoot, as the inhabited terrain mostly mandated no practical necessity for footwear.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} The Egyptians and Hindus made some use of ornamental footwear, such as a soleless [[sandal]] known as a ''Cleopatra'', which did not provide any practical protection for the foot. Athletes in the [[Ancient Olympic Games]] participated barefoot and generally unclothed.{{cite news|title=Unearthing the First Spartan Boys where not allowed to wear shoes to toughen their feet and allow stronger dexterity in their toes Olympics|url=https://www.npr.org/programs/re/archivesdate/2004/jul/nemea/|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[NPR]]|date=July 19, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728000414/http://www.npr.org/programs/re/archivesdate/2004/jul/nemea/|archivedate=2010-07-28|deadurl=yes|df=}} Even the [[Twelve Olympians|gods]] and heroes were primarily depicted barefoot. The [[Ancient Rome|Romans]], who eventually conquered the Greeks and adopted many aspects of their culture, did not adopt the Greek perception of footwear and clothing. [[Clothing in ancient Rome|Roman clothing]] explicitly including footwear was seen as a sign of power and as a necessity of living in a civilized world; accordingly slaves usually were to remain barefoot.{{cite book|last=Frazine|first=Richard Keith|title=The Barefoot Hiker|year=1993|publisher=Ten Speed Press|isbn=0-89815-525-8|page=98|url=https://books.google.com/?id=edsITVCd2G0C&printsec=frontcover&dq=barefoot+hiker&q}} There are many references to shoes being worn in the [[Bible]]. During weddings of this period, a father would give his son-in-law a pair of shoes to symbolize the transfer of authority.{{cite web|title=77 Interesting Facts About Weddings|url=http://facts.randomhistory.com/interesting-facts-about-weddings.html|publisher=randomhistory.com|accessdate=July 1, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100723234251/http://facts.randomhistory.com/interesting-facts-about-weddings.html| archivedate= 23 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} During the Middle Ages, both men and women wore [[Patten (shoe)|pattens]] in Europe, commonly seen as the predecessor of the modern [[high-heeled footwear|high-heeled shoe]],{{cite web|title=Dangerous Elegance: A History of High-Heeled Shoes|url=http://www.randomhistory.com/1-50/036heels.html|publisher=randomhistory.com|accessdate=July 1, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100728002338/http://www.randomhistory.com/1-50/036heels.html| archivedate= 28 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} while menial classes usually wore hand-made footwear out of available materials. Going barefoot was seen as a marker of poverty and the lowest social class, as well as being the mark of a prisoner (see below). In the 15th century, [[chopine]]s were created in [[Turkey]] and were usually 7–8 inches (17.7–20.3 cm) high. These shoes became popular in [[Venice]] and throughout Europe as a [[status symbol]] revealing wealth and social standing. During the 16th century royalty, such as [[Catherine de Medici]] and [[Mary I of England]], started wearing high-heeled shoes to make them look taller or larger than life. By 1580, even men wore them, and a person with authority or wealth was often referred to as "well-heeled". The phrase ''[[barefoot and pregnant]]'' is now used to illustrate a woman's traditional role as a [[homemaker]] and thus her lack of opportunities to socialize or to have a career outside of the home.{{cite news|last=Newman|first=Ruth I.|title=Ozarks Women: Ignorant, Barefoot, and Pregnant?|url=http://thelibrary.springfield.missouri.org/lochist/periodicals/wrv/V9/N8/s87c.htm|accessdate=June 29, 2010|newspaper=West River Valley Historical Quarterly|date=December 22, 2002}} It was first used in the early 20th century, possibly by Arthur E. Hertzler (also known as the "Kansas Horse-and-Buggy Doctor"),{{cite book|last=Hashinger|first=Edward H.|title=Arthur E. Hertzler: The Kansas Horse-and-Buggy Doctor|year=1961|publisher=University of Kansas Press|pmc=1574475}} promoting a hypothesis that:{{cite news|last=Peck|first=Joseph H.|title=It's All Right to Keep Her Happy, But, Men, Don't Do Her Chores|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sM4TAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ruIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4809,3737819&dq=barefoot-and-pregnant&hl=en|newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard|date=May 21, 1958}} {{cquote|The only way to keep a woman happy is to keep her barefoot and pregnant.}} [[File:Udaipur girl.jpg|thumb|Barefoot girl in [[Udaipur]], India]] Bare feet have come to symbolize innocence or childhood in a glorifying perception of freedom from real-life requirements. The connection to childhood and innocence, as well as the simple joys of country life, are embodied in the poem "[[The Barefoot Boy]]" by [[John Greenleaf Whittier]], published in 1855.{{cite book|last=Ravitch|first=Diane|title=The American reader: words that moved a nation| year=2000| publisher=HarperCollins| isbn=0-06-273733-3| pages=140–43| url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZhJQCsOCgGgC&pg=PA140&lpg=PA140&dq=the+barefoot+boy+by+john+greenleaf+whittier&q=the%20barefoot%20boy%20by%20john%20greenleaf%20whittier}} Additionally, the book ''[[Dancing Barefoot (book)|Dancing Barefoot]]'' by ''[[Star Trek: The Next Generation]]'' actor [[Wil Wheaton]] features five short stories that chronicle his journey from childhood and youth through to maturity and self-acceptance.{{cite book|last=Wheaton|first=Wil|title=Dancing Barefoot|year=2004|publisher=Monolith Press|isbn=0-596-00674-8|page=120|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gDG67vii624C&printsec=frontcover&dq=dancing+barefoot&q}} ===Religious aspects=== In most religions, the exposure of bare feet is regarded as a sign of humility and subjection. Some religious practitioners have taken a vow of Gospel poverty, while there are certain convents where going barefoot is obligatory ([[Convent of Las Descalzas Reales]], [[Poor Clares]], [[Colettine Poor Clares]]). With regard to the use of footwear as a display of status, the religious and common art of many cultures throughout the world shows a person without shoes symbolizing either extreme poverty or the state of captivity and unfree servitude.{{cite book|last=DeMello|first=Margo|title=Feet and Footwear: A Cultural Encyclopedia|year=2009|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-313-35714-5|pages=30–32|url=https://books.google.com/?id=5QdKSxajwP0C&pg=PA30&lpg=PA30&dq=barefoot+middle+ages&q=barefoot%20middle%20ages}} In [[Thailand]], Master Jinshen, a [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] monk, walks {{convert|20|km|mi|sp=us}} per day barefoot as a reminder to others who pursue a material life to protect and be concerned for [[Mother Nature]]. He states that he does this to follow Buddhist rules, to lead the people to the path of virtue, and to develop his Buddhist spirit.{{cite news|last=Lin|first=You Hsueh|title=Thai monk walks million miles on barefoot|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Asia/Story/A1Story20100213-198496.html|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[Asia One News]]|date=February 13, 2010}} It is customary in Judaism and some Christian denominations to go barefoot while mourning. Some Christian churches practice barefoot [[pilgrimage]] traditions, such as the ascent of [[Croagh Patrick]] in Ireland at night while barefoot (although the nighttime part is no longer encouraged).{{cite news|title=Mayo Mountain Rescue Team appeal to pilgrims for safety on holy mountain|url=http://www.castlebar.ie/news/article_2671.shtml|accessdate=June 29, 2010|newspaper=Castlebar News|date=July 24, 2006}} In many religions, it is common to remove shoes when entering a place considered holy. For example, in the [[Book of Exodus]], [[Moses]] was instructed to remove his shoes before approaching the burning bush: {{cquote|Put off thy shoes from off thy feet, for the place whereon thou standest [is] holy ground ({{bibleverse|Exodus|3:5|KJV}}).}} Anyone entering a [[mosque]] or a [[Hindu temple]], including a visitor, is expected to remove his or her shoes; racks for the storage of shoes are usually provided at the entrance.{{cite web|url=http://goseasia.about.com/od/travelplanning/a/mosque-dos-and-donts.htm|title=Mosque etiquette|work=Southeast Asia travel|publisher=about.com|accessdate=10 August 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.asia.si.edu/pujaonline/puja/temples.html|title=Worship in Hindu temples|publisher=pujaonline|accessdate=10 August 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625094917/http://www.asia.si.edu/pujaonline/puja/temples.html#|archive-date=2012-06-25|dead-url=yes|df=}} [[Foot washing]], or ceremonial washing of others' feet, is associated with humility in Christianity, and Jesus Christ is recorded in the [[New Testament]] as washing the feet of his disciples to serve them during the [[Last Supper]]. Christians who practice foot washing today do so to bring them closer to Jesus and to fill them with a sense of humility and service. [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholics]] show their respect and humility for the [[Pope]] by kissing his feet. In a similar manner, Hindus show love and respect to a [[guru]] by touching his bare feet (called [[pranam]]). It is customary to show one's respect by walking barefoot around [[Raj Ghat]], the monument to [[Mahatma Gandhi]]. Both United States President [[George W. Bush]] and [[Pope John Paul II]] paid him this honor.{{cite news|title=Barefoot Bush pays tribute to Mahatma|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/Barefoot-Bush-pays-tribute-to-Mahatma/articleshow/1436126.cms|accessdate=June 29, 2010|newspaper=The Times of India|date=March 3, 2006}} During the [[Imperial Japan]]ese period, removing one's shoes in the presence of a person of higher status was a sign of showing one's own humility, subordination, and respect towards their status. Christian congregations of men and women that go entirely barefoot or wear sandals include the [[Discalced]], like the [[Discalced Carmelites]] (1568), the [[Congregation of the Feuillants|Feuillants]] ([[Cistercians]], 1575), the [[Trinitarian Order|Trinitarians]] (1594), the [[Order of the Blessed Virgin Mary of Mercy|Mercedarians]] (1604), and the [[Passionist]]s.{{catholic}} In many branches of [[Romani culture]] across the world, it is traditional for women to dance barefoot. ===Firewalking=== [[Firewalking]] is the practice of walking barefoot over hot coals. It has been practiced by many people and cultures in all parts of the world, with the earliest known reference dating back to [[Iron Age India]] – c. 1200 BC.{{cite web|last=Willey|first=David|title=Firewalking Myth vs Physics|url=http://www.pitt.edu/~dwilley/Fire/FireTxt/fire.html|publisher=[[University of Pittsburgh]]|accessdate=June 29, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100606040454/http://www.pitt.edu/~dwilley/Fire/FireTxt/fire.html| archivedate= 6 June 2010 | deadurl= no}} It is often used as a [[rite of passage]], as a test of an individual's strength and courage, or, in religion, as a test of one's faith. Today, it is often used in corporate and team-building seminars and self-help workshops as a confidence-building exercise. Firewalking implies the belief that the feat requires the aid of a supernatural force, strong faith, or on an individual's ability to focus on "mind over matter". Modern physics has largely debunked this, showing that the amount of time the foot is in contact with the ground is not enough to induce a burn, combined with the fact that [[coal]] is not a very good conductor of heat. ==Barefoot customs by country== {{globalize|date=June 2015}} ===Australia=== It is common for Australians, particularly young people, to be barefoot in public places, especially during summer.{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/life/weekend-australian-magazine/season-of-the-shoeless/story-e6frg8h6-1226732901337 |title=Season of the shoeless |publisher=Theaustralian.com.au |accessdate=2015-11-27}} [[McDonald's]] launched a summer advertisement in 2012 featuring a customer running barefoot through the hot carpark to the restaurant.{{cite web|url=http://www.campaignbrief.com/2012/11/mcdonalds-gets-set-for-summer.html |title=McDonald's gets set for summer with launch of 'Do Summer' campaign via DDB Sydney |publisher=Campaignbrief.com Australia|date= |accessdate=2015-11-27}} In some rural and remote areas, such as the [[Northern Territory]], Western NSW, regional Queensland and many islands, students often attend school barefoot. On [[Lord Howe Island]] the [[Lord Howe Island Board]] has described the fact pupils at the government-run Lord Howe Island Central School are allowed to attend school barefoot as a part of the "island lifestyle" and a "community asset".{{cite web|url=http://www.lhib.nsw.gov.au/sites/lordhowe/files/public/images/documents/lhib/Community/lhi%20community%20strategy%20final%20august%202010.pdf |format=PDF |title=Lord Howe Island Community Strategy |publisher=Lhib.nsw.gov.au |accessdate=2015-11-27}} ===New Zealand=== In 2010, an American lecturer missed out on a job after criticising barefoot locals in a newspaper.{{cite web|last=Page |first=Emma |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/3203837/Attack-on-shoeless-Kiwis-costs-lecturer-job |title=Attack on shoeless Kiwis costs lecturer job |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date=2010-01-03 |accessdate=2015-11-27}} The lecturer wrote barefoot locals were "not only backward and uncivilised, but dangerously unhygienic and repulsive to North Americans" in response to an article mocking a no shoes, no service policy in Texas. In 2012, a travel writer for ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote the number of New Zealanders barefoot in public, including shops was "striking".{{cite web|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/striking-number-kiwis-walk-around-barefoot-ny-times-4835491|title='Striking' number of Kiwis walk around barefoot |last=|first=|date=April 16, 2012|website=tvnz.co.nz|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150614055413/http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/striking-number-kiwis-walk-around-barefoot-ny-times-4835491|archivedate=June 14, 2015|deadurl=yes|accessdate=June 12, 2015}} Many expats in New Zealand have been surprised how many people, of all races and classes, carry on daily business barefoot{{cite web|url=http://mccabe.net.nz/going-naked-barefoot-in-new-zealand/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528105136/http://mccabe.net.nz/going-naked-barefoot-in-new-zealand/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-05-28 |title=Going naked: barefoot in New Zealand |publisher=Mccabe.net.nz |date=2014-03-26 |accessdate=2017-03-06}} In 2014, [[Air New Zealand]] was subject of critical attention after allegedly forcing a customer to wear shoes.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=11186434 |author=Danielle Murray| title=Bare feet soothing to the sole and the soul |publisher= Life & Style – NZ Herald News |website=Nzherald.co.nz |date=2014-01-15 |accessdate=2015-11-27}} ===United Kingdom=== {{expand section|date=November 2015}} [[File:Newhaven boy ('King Fisher' or 'His Faither's Breeks').jpg|thumb|upright|A barefooted Scottish boy c1845 - Robert Adamson]] Being barefoot in public is more common during warmer months, and often accepted as a social norm, however this does not extend to metropolitan cities such as London, but more for rural areas and more common for young children and teenagers. Some British schools also allow children to attend school barefoot in warmer months, and encourage it for indoor and outdoor physical education lessons. The [[National Health Service]] has recommended that people "go barefoot or wear open-toed sandals whenever you can in the hot weather...to help stop your feet getting sweaty and smelly."{{cite web|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Livewell/foothealth/Pages/Summerfeet.aspx |title=Summer feet tips |publisher=Nhs.uk Choices|date=2014-04-14 |accessdate=2015-11-27}} ===South Africa=== In South Africa barefoot walking in public is part of the predominantly white Afrikaans speaking culture, although English speaking people also often walk barefoot in public, especially in the summer months and in cities such as Cape Town. The National Guidelines on School Uniform list shoes as an optional item{{cite web|url=http://www.education.gov.za/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=8NYok1lRKBs%3D&tabid=453&mid=469 |title=Schedule : National Guidelines on School Uniform |publisher=Education.gov.za |accessdate=2015-11-27}} while the Draft Guidelines state "Pupils, especially in lower grades, should also be permitted to attend without shoes in hot weather". Most children attend school barefoot. In many schools, the dress codes either encourage kids to attend school barefoot or prefer kids to attend school barefoot, especially in the summer months. Some South African schools have sport uniforms where bare feet are compulsory, such as primary school rugby. Another sport where bare feet for kids are compulsory is "tou trek" or tug of war. Being barefoot in public is generally tolerated. In South African shopping malls, stores, and events, it is not an uncommon sight to see barefoot adults, kids and especially teenagers and young adults. === United States === In some parts of the United States, where [[taboos]] against barefoot walking are strong, it is common for people to wear the same shoes indoors and outdoors, and for guests to keep their shoes on when visiting other people's houses. {{citation needed|date=October 2017}} Youngstown, Ohio, actually did have an ordinance prohibiting barefooting until it was struck down as unconstitutional.{{cite web|title=Gadsden Times |date=April 23, 1969|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1891&dat=19690423&id=-KsfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=x9YEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5080,3238801|ref=Youngstown barefoot ordinance}} However, in the early 18th to 20th century many children in rural areas of America often went barefoot due to poverty.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} Many stores, restaurants, and other public venues in the United States employ [[dress code]]s prohibiting bare feet.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} While private business owners are free to set their own policies, many cite different health regulations, though these typically are [[occupational safety]] requirements that pertain to employees only. {{citation needed|date=October 2017}} == Imprisonment and slavery == {{slavery}} [[File:Cornelis De Wael - To Visit the Imprisoned - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Depiction of barefooted prisoners by [[Cornelis de Wael]]; ''To Visit the Imprisoned'' c. 1640]] [[File:1838 Joanna frontispiece Narrative byStedman engr byGeorgeGSmith NYPL.jpeg|thumb|upright|Barefooted female slave in South America]] Removing the footwear and making a captive go barefoot has been one of the first conventional methods to tag and identify [[prisoner]]s in most civilizations. It was a usual feature and often the principle element of early [[prison uniform]]s. The visual aspect of bare feet is therefore used to contrast the conventional appearance as footwear is regarded an obligatory clothing feature in urbanized cultures. Besides the indicatory aspect going in bare feet restricts the freedom of action in many situations. A barefooted person is therefore disadvantaged opposite a shod person in many practical respects. This aspect is often used to exercise physical control over individuals in captivity. A barefoot person is usually disadvantaged in a physical confrontation against shod individuals. Drastically more severe injuries can be sustained especially by a kicking person outfitted with footwear in contrast to a person in bare feet. For this reason shoes are considered [[deadly weapon]]s by [[penal law]]s of most countries.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} Bare feet on the other hand present an opportune and vulnerable target for the application of force. These effects are usually desired by correctional or police officers primarily in confrontational situations with antagonistic individuals. The risk of personal injury is therefore notably reduced and the situation can often be resolved more efficiently. Another main objective is preventing and counteracting potential attempts of [[prison escape]]. Without the protection of the feet that shoes provide, the locomotion of an unshod person is more difficult in the majority of exterior environments, so a potential fugitive is easier to retrieve in many cases. Detainees are often discouraged from attempting escape by this measure alone.{{cite news|title=Police capture man who escaped from Tewksbury police station.|url=http://www.lowellsun.com/breakingnews/ci_18259469|accessdate=September 16, 2014}} A barefoot person experiences certain discomfort in daily life situations. The desire to be protected from the common inconveniences of the ground, mostly due to coarse textures or adverse temperatures, prompted humans to make use of footwear in [[ancient history]]. Incidentally the traditional visual appearance of civilized societies was established, including footwear as an obligatory feature. A forced exclusion from the conveniences and also appearance of footwear typically creates an frequent awareness of being vulnerable, therefore it can have an intimidating effect on a person. The enforcement of bare feet often creates a consciousness of being powerless and degraded notably on prisoners, as they typically cannot relieve this situation on their own.{{cite news|title=Long hours in a Harare jail.|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/2018917.stm|accessdate=July 18, 2012|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=June 1, 2002}} As the practical effects are typically achieved effortlessly, keeping captives or prisoners barefoot has been cross-culturally practiced since antiquity.{{cite web|title=Biblical studies: Footwear.|url=https://www.bibelwissenschaft.de/stichwort/27353/|accessdate=August 6, 2015}} It was also commonly practiced to identify [[slavery|slaves]] in former times. ===Slave codes=== [[File:Jean-Léon Gérôme - The Slave Market - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|upright|Barefooted oriental slaves (''Jean-Léon Gérôme – The Slave Market'')]] [[File:Slave dance to banjo, 1780s.jpg|thumb|Barefooted slaves in North America, 1780s]] Since ancient times, it is a common practice in civil societies to wear footwear as a standard feature. In contrast to this convention, ''slave codes'' often decreed that slaves go barefoot. For example, the [[Cape Town]] slave code stated that "Slaves must go barefoot and must carry passes."{{cite web|title=Cape Town and Surrounds.|url=http://www.westerncape.gov.za/eng/pubs/public_info/P/82884/3/|publisher=westerncape.gov.za|accessdate=July 18, 2012}} This was the case in the majority of states that abolished slavery later in history, as most images from the respective historical period suggest that slaves were barefoot.{{cite web|title=Slavery in Brazil.|url=http://histclo.com/act/work/slave/am/cou/bra/sab-sla.html|publisher=Historical Boys' Clothing]accessdate=July 18, 2012}} To quote Brother Riemer (1779): "[the slaves] are, even in their most beautiful suit, obliged to go barefoot. Slaves were forbidden to wear shoes. This was a prime mark of distinction between the free and the bonded and no exceptions were permitted." {{cite web|title=Living conditions of slaves.|url=http://surinamslavery.blogspot.com/2008/10/chapter-6-living-conditions-of-slaves.html|publisher=Historical Boys' Clothing]accessdate=July 18, 2012}} Shoes have been regarded as badges of freedom and signs of empowerment since early human history, while going barefoot designated a rather low social rank, often having the status of an unfree person. Using the symbolic meaning of shoes to display a respectable social status and also being vested with authority, people have ceremonially been issued with footwear as is mentioned in the bible "But the father said to his servants, Bring forth the best robe, and put [it] on him; and put a ring on his hand, and shoes on [his] feet ({{bibleverse|Luke|15:22|KJV}})". Forcing individuals to go barefoot by taking away their shoes and disallowing or hindering them to be worn accordingly has the reversed meaning. While since ancient societies the standard form of appearance commonly includes footwear as an implicit feature, the imagery or bare feet is often used to indicate submission, subjugation or dependence, in certain contexts also being disarmed or disempowered.
Therefore, this detail has become an informal and sometimes even formal law in societies practicing slavery. A barefooted human could be unmistakably identified as unfree and be attributed with the lowest social status on the spot. As a consequence appearing barefooted in any social situation was proscribed for common citizens and strictly avoided.
In many US states this perception is prevalent to this day as everyday shoes are typically also worn in the private space and being barefooted is effectively placed under taboo (see [[Barefoot#Cultural aspects|above]]). In certain societies this rule pertains to this day where slavery is still unofficially practiced. The [[Tuareg]] are known still to practice slavery and force their slaves to go barefoot.{{Cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/s/RubDDBDABB9457A437BAA85A49C26FB23A0/Doc~E19E0D1A29403492E9787E7A392A3FFAE~ATpl~Ecommon~Scontent.html|title=Niger: Ehemalige Sklavin erhält Entschädigung |last=Scheen|first=Von Thomas|date=2008-10-31|website=faz.net|language=DE|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081031151116/http://www.faz.net/s/RubDDBDABB9457A437BAA85A49C26FB23A0/Doc~E19E0D1A29403492E9787E7A392A3FFAE~ATpl~Ecommon~Scontent.html|archive-date=2008-10-31|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-08-23}} ===Imprisonment=== In several countries of the world [[prison]] inmates have to remain barefoot under regulatory constraint. In history this was common practice in most civilizations as bare feet were commonly received as a characteristic of unfree individuals. It also marked the first means of visually marking [[prisoner]]s in terms of a [[prison uniform]]. This is current practice in [[China]],{{cite web|url=http://www.clearharmony.net/articles/The_Chinese_Prison_System_I_Know-a23068.html|title=The Chinese Prison System I Know|author=A Falun Dafa practitioner in Guangxi Province of China|work=clearharmony.net}} [[Zimbabwe]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/may/12/pressandpublishing.observercampaignpressfreedom|title=My night in Mugabe's stinking jail|author=Andrew Meldrum|work=the Guardian}}{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatches/globalpost-blogs/chatter/zimbabwes-jails-full-human-kindness|title=Zimbabwe's jails: full of human kindness?|work=GlobalPost}} [[Thailand]],{{cite web|url=http://www.phaseloop.com/foreignprisoners/case-steve_willcox01.html|title=Foreign Prisoners Support Service|work=phaseloop.com}}{{cite web |url=http://phuketwan.com/tourism/trip-inside-phuket-prison-photo-special/ |title=A Trip Inside Phuket Prison: Photo Special |publisher=Phuket Wan |date= |accessdate=2015-11-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208131350/http://phuketwan.com/tourism/trip-inside-phuket-prison-photo-special/ |archive-date=2015-12-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }} [[Uganda]],{{cite web|url=http://www.dispatchesinternational.org/?p=66|title=Open Minds, Closed Doors: Prison Education in Uganda|work=DI News|access-date=2014-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129084805/http://www.dispatchesinternational.org/?p=66|archive-date=2014-11-29|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/750184/Barefoot-prisoners-bury-Uganda-cult-bodies.html?pg=all|title=Barefoot prisoners bury Uganda cult bodies|date=20 March 2000|work=DeseretNews.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.byliner.com/robert-j-rosenthal/stories/inside-a-ugandan-prison-a-nightmare-comes-to-life|title=Inside a Ugandan Prison, a Nightmare Comes to Life|last=Rosenthal|first=Robert J.|authorlink=Robert Jon Rosenthal|date=January 1982|website=byliner.com|publisher=The Philadelphia Inquirer|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007013357/http://byliner.com/robert-j-rosenthal/stories/inside-a-ugandan-prison-a-nightmare-comes-to-life|archivedate=October 7, 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=September 15, 2014}} [[Iran]],{{cite web|url=http://aclj.org/iran/american-pastor-saeed-facing-hell-on-earth-in-iran-evin-prison|title=American Pastor Saeed Facing "Hell on Earth" in Iran's Evin Prison |work=American Center for Law and Justice}} [[Pakistan]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7zzPCNmdIt8|title=Prison conditions in Pakistan|date=31 December 1969|work=YouTube}} [[India]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iaLzI3aNNWU|title=How One Woman Helped Reform a Notorious Indian Prison|date=31 December 1969|work=YouTube}} [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]],{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201308060919.html|title=allAfrica.com: Congo-Kinshasa: Meet 'Mr Human Rights'|work=allAfrica.com}} [[Malawi]],{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/erica-solomon/i-live-here-documentary_b_910894.html|title='I Live Here' – Introducing the Boys of Kachere Juvenile Prison |author= Erica Solomon|work=The Huffington Post}} [[Rwanda]],{{cite web|url=http://globaldiscussion.net/topic/1814-worlds-toughest-prisons/|title=World's Toughest Prisons|work=The Voice of Russia's Global Discussion|access-date=2014-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006103458/http://globaldiscussion.net/topic/1814-worlds-toughest-prisons/|archive-date=2014-10-06|dead-url=yes|df=}} [[Côte d’Ivoire]] (Ivory Coast),{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/fr/report/54460/cote-d-ivoire-when-a-sentence-to-jail-can-be-a-sentence-to-death|title=Cote d'Ivoire: When a sentence to jail can be a sentence to death |work=IRINnewsCote d'Ivoire – Droits de l'homme}} and [[North Korea]]{{cite web|url=http://www.northkoreanrefugees.com/testimony2.htm|title=Life Funds for North Korean Refugees, an NGO|work=northkoreanrefugees.com}} among others. In Thailand, a [[defendant]] in [[Criminal justice|penal proceedings]] traditionally must remain barefoot for courtroom appearances.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/07/04/1057179158262.html|title=Australian addict welcomes 31-year prison term|work=smh.com.au}}{{cite web|url=http://www.irishecho.com.au/2010/06/30/irish-australian-man-facing-jail-in-thailand/4005|title=Irish Australian man facing jail in Thailand|work=irishecho.com.au|access-date=2014-09-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140929202354/http://www.irishecho.com.au/2010/06/30/irish-australian-man-facing-jail-in-thailand/4005|archive-date=2014-09-29|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thaiprisonlife.com/blogs/a-foreigner-in-a-thai-court/|title=A Foreigner in a Thai Court|work=Thai Prison Life – ชีวิตในเรือนจำ}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/bc-pedophile-homeward-bound-after-thai-prison-term-arrested-at-vancouver-airport/article4577486/|title=B.C. pedophile, homeward bound after Thai prison term, arrested at Vancouver airport|work=The Globe and Mail}}{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/01/23/world/asia/thailand-activist-prison-sentence/|title=Thai court sentences activist to 10 years in prison for insulting king |author=Kocha Olarn|date=23 January 2013|work=CNN}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/07/04/1057179158696.html|title= |work=theage.com.au}}{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2008/07/29/2003418810|title=Extradition hearing for arms dealer postponed|work=taipeitimes.com}} In [[Germany]] it was common practice during the [[Nazism|Nazi-era]] to keep especially female prisoners uniformly barefoot. In particular camps the women also had to perform forced labor in their bare feet, at times even under adverse weather conditions. This was implemented as means to intimidate the detained individuals and dampen renitency as well as to reduce the expenses for clothing items. It was also part of the then prevalent practice in Nazi-Germany to victimize prisoners.{{cite book |first=Rochelle G. |last=Saidel |title=The Jewish Women of Ravensbruck Concentration Camp |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=zglu2RvoLmgC&pg=PA17&dq=1941+uniforms+barefoot&hl=en&sa=X&ei=D45RUeXsBIe14AT_qoDABg&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=1941%20uniforms%20barefoot&f=false|accessdate=March 26, 2013}}{{cite book |first=Jan Erik |last=Schulte |title=Konzentrationslager im Rheinland und in Westfalen 1933–1945. Zwischen zentraler Steuerung und regionaler Initiative |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F26hGF3OU-0C&pg=PA157&dq=barfu%C3%9F+gefangene&hl=en&sa=X&ei=kZ1PUY3_J8LGtQbg-4GQAw&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=barfu%C3%9F%20gefangene&f=false }}{{cite web |title=Brandenburgische Landeszentrale für politische Bildung |url=http://www.politische-bildung-brandenburg.de/publikationen/pdf/fehrbellin.pdf|format=PDF}} Within women's penitentiaries in [[socialism|socialist]] [[East Germany]] (German Democratic Republic) especially [[political prisoner]]s who were regarded as opponents of the regime could have their footwear seized and be detained barefoot as an aggravation of their penalty.{{cite web|url=http://www.morgenpost.de/familie/article1924314/Das-Unrecht-verfolgt-mich-bis-an-mein-Lebensende.html|title=DDR-Gefängnis Hoheneck: 'Das Unrecht verfolgt mich – bis an mein Lebensende' |author=Maggie Riepl|date=10 March 2012|work=Berliner Morgenpost |location= Berlin}} The earmarking of captives by forcing them to go in bare feet was also practiced specifically on imprisoned women in parts of the United States until the early 20th century. It was then common practice by penal institutions particularly in [[Texas]] to exclude female prisoners from being issued with any kind of footwear, by this means keeping them barefoot throughout. Contrary to this measure adequate shoes were provided for male convicts as a matter of course. There were no apparent security motives for this unequal treatment; it was however practiced to point out the evident [[hierarchy]] between male and female detainees. The according structure of subordination of the female prisoners also towards the male convicts was therefore showcased in an evident and palpable way. It also conformed to the notion of the criminal courts, who widely saw prisoners as official slaves of the state.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cliffsnotes.com/study-guides/criminal-justice/prisons-and-prisoners-rights/prisoners-rights|title=Prisoners' Rights|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cliffsnotes.com|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160522040456/http://www.cliffsnotes.com/study-guides/criminal-justice/prisons-and-prisoners-rights/prisoners-rights|archive-date=2016-05-22|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-08-23|df=}} In this an [[analogy]] to actual former slaves was drawn, who were often forced to remain barefoot as well (see above). As going shoeless is placed under a more or less strict social taboo in most regions of the US (see above), being forced to go entirely barefoot determined the degradation to the lowest social rank for the incarcerated women. This arbitrary and victimizing measure was an apparent token for the general [[discrimination]] against incarcerated women, who unlike male prisoners did not have the right to claim legal remedies at that time.{{cite book |first=Anne M. |last=Butler |title=Gendered Justice in the American West: Women Prisoners in Men's Penitentiaries |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p4IdxKAdM8cC&pg=PA134&dq=texas+worked+at+the+farm+camps+barefoot&hl=es&sa=X&ei=VZpMUar1Gsrfswa53YC4Ag&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=texas%20worked%20at%20the%20farm%20camps%20barefoot&f=false|accessdate=March 22, 2013}}{{cite book |title= Women in Prison: A Reference Handbook |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DpSjVQ0u9zwC&pg=PA35&dq=texas+worked+at+the+farm+camps+barefoot&hl=es&sa=X&ei=VZpMUar1Gsrfswa53YC4Ag&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=texas%20worked%20at%20the%20farm%20camps%20barefoot&f=false |accessdate=March 22, 2013}}{{cite book |author1=Gordon Moris Bakken |author2=Brenda Farrington |title=Encyclopedia of Women in the American West|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U9zIeyugktEC&pg=PA150&dq=texas+worked+at+the+farm+camps+barefoot&hl=es&sa=X&ei=VZpMUar1Gsrfswa53YC4Ag&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=texas%20worked%20at%20the%20farm%20camps%20barefoot&f=false |accessdate=March 22, 2013}} In the present ISIS usually deprives their captives of footwear, presumably in order to identify them more readily and prevent escape.{{cite web|url=http://www.bestgore.com/execution/isis-video-truckloads-men-lead-to-slaughter-execution/|title=ISIS removes shoes of captives|work=smh.com.au}} In the bible there are multiple passages stating that a potent way to inflict humiliation on another human being lies in taking away his or her shoes and forcing the individual to go barefoot. Ritual customs therefore consisted of publicly taking away a disgraced person's shoes. This resulted in the individual being defamed as a "barefooter" culminating in the loss of social standing. On the other hand, taking off the shoes of one's own will and voluntarily exposing one's bare feet is regarded as a token of submission and humility by the bible. This included the subjection under higher powers as well as a mundane authority. Therefore, it was concluded to be imperative that prisoners or captives were to be kept barefoot and in light clothing as a token of their subjugation. ===Inquisition and witch trials=== During the era of the Catholic [[Inquisition]] it was commonly believed that women practicing [[witchcraft]] had their ability to use sinister powers largely diminished if they were forced to remain barefoot. As a consequence first of all the just arrested woman routinely had her footwear taken away, ensuring that her feet remained unclothed at all events. Due to interpretations of the ''[[Malleus Maleficarum]]'' it was believed that in case a witch was not strictly kept in her bare feet she could still cast a spell on people by just looking at them. As the prosecutors wanted to avoid any risk, it was seen to it that the bare feet of the accused woman were constantly visible, so to convince themselves at any moment. During questioning or in court the accused women often had to stand on a consecrated spot with the soles of their bare feet touching the sanctified area. This was believed to completely inhibit any of their purported magic powers. Accordingly, the women were forbidden to look at the prosecutors when their bare feet were not strictly in place. To further ensure safety they were often lead in walking backwards when facing the prosecution. They were allowed to turn around only if their bare feet could clearly be seen to be within the bounded spot. As the accused women naturally could not use any magic while they were tried, this assumption became an accepted doctrine. Accordingly, contemporary depictions about inquisition proceedings or similar situations portray the tried women barefooted in almost every case.''Das verhexte Kloster: Nach den Akten dargestellt'' (trans. ''The bewitched cloister: portrayed according to official records'') by [[Anton Memminger]], published 1904. p. 137. ==Corporal punishment== [[File:Foot whipping.JPG|thumb|Demonstration of "bastinado"]] The [[Sole (foot)|soles]] of a person's bare feet also serve as a target for [[corporal punishment]], commonly referred to as "bastinado" ([[foot whipping]]). This method is mainly used in the context of penal functions and situations of detention or incarceration. The practice of foot whipping is still officially employed in several [[Middle East]]ern nations where the term ''falaka'' is customary. In history, bastinado was frequently practiced in Western countries as well. Among others, it was commonly used in [[Germany|German]] territories, where it was employed until the end of the [[Nazism|Nazi-era]], mainly within the [[reformatory]] and [[Detention (imprisonment)|detention]] system. In certain facilities it even continued to be used during the 1950s.{{cite web|title=Wimmersdorf: 270 Schläge auf die Fußsohlen|url=http://kurier.at/chronik/niederoesterreich/wimmersdorf-270-schlaege-auf-die-fusssohlen/30.980.261|work=kurier.at| accessdate=2014-03-03|trans-title=Wimmersdorf: 270 blows on the soles of the feet|language=de}}{{cite web|url=http://www.krone.at/Oesterreich/Berichte_ueber_Folter_in_Kinder-Heim_auf_der_Hohen_Warte-Schwere_Vorwuerfe-Story-316489|title=Berichte über Folter in Kinder-Heim auf der Hohen Warte|work=krone.at}}''Torture and Democracy'' von Darius Rejali. S. 275.Ruxandra Cesereanu: ''An Overview of Political Torture in the Twentieth Century''. pp. 124f. The beatings usually aim at the muscular tissue within the vaults of the foot ([[longitudinal arch of the foot]]), omitting the bone structure of the ball and the heel. The vaults are highly touch-sensitive and therefore susceptible to pain due to the tight clustering of [[nerve|nerve endings]]. As bastinado causes substantial suffering for the victim while [[physical evidence]] remains largely undetectable after some time, it is frequently used for [[interrogation]] and [[torture]] in rogue regimes as well.''Torture and Democracy'' by Darius Rejali. pp. 275f. ==Arts and entertainment== Many singers and dancers perform on stage barefoot. The classical dance of [[Cambodia]] had its roots in the holy dances of the legendary seductresses (''[[apsaras]]'') of ancient Cambodia and attained its high point during the [[Angkor]] period in its interpretations of the Indian epics, especially the ''[[Ramayana]]''. Cambodian dancers were well-born women of the king's harem and danced barefoot, with the feet turned outwards and the legs slightly bent at the knee to cushion the movements of the upper body. The unimpeded movement of the foot was essential to the art. When the land was invaded by the Thai, the dancers were taken to the Thai court, where their art was adapted and continued to flourish.{{cite book |author=Colet, John|author2=Joshua Eliot|author3=Abigail Vertigan |year=2002 |title=Cambodian Handbook |publisher=Footprint |isbn=1-903471-40-0 |page=218 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=3nVUxKL29ZwC&pg=PA218&dq=cambodia+dance+bare+foot+feet&q}}{{cite book |author=Brown, Ian |year=2000 |title=Cambodia |publisher=Oxfam GB |isbn=0-85598-430-9 |page=71 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=bK11j2IdbC0C&pg=PA71&dq=cambodia+dance+bare+foot+feet&q}} The barefoot dance movement of the early 20th century challenged the received laws of classical dance and the broader laws of social decorum. For decades, the bare foot had been perceived as obscene, and no matter how determined barefoot dancers were to validate their art with reference to spiritual, artistic, historic, and organic concepts, barefoot dancing was inextricably linked in the public mind with indecency and sexual taboo. In 1908, [[Maud Allan]] shocked and fascinated London theatre-goers with her barefoot dance of desire in ''Salome'', and scandalous tributes positioned her as the embodiment of lust. For many, barefoot dancing represented not only the freedom and horror of modern sexuality but the progress and decline of high culture.{{cite book |editor1=Benstock, Shari |editor2=Ferriss, Suzanne |year=2001 |title=Footnotes: On Shoes |publisher=Rutgers University Press |isbn=0-8135-2870-4 |pages=276–78 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=tUK8BP7OOJQC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Footnotes:+On+Shoes&q}} [[File:Isadora Duncan (grayscale).jpg|thumb|upright|left|Dancer [[Isadora Duncan]] performing barefoot during her 1915–18 American tour]] [[California]]n [[Isadora Duncan]] revolutionized dance in the Western world by jettisoning the [[Ballet tutu|tutu]] and the [[pointe shoe]] of classical [[ballet]] and scandalized audiences by performing works of her own choreography in flowing draperies and bare feet. She anticipated the modern [[women's liberation movement]] by urging women to rid themselves of corsets and matrimony.{{cite book |author=Needham, Maureen |year=2002 |title=I See America Dancing: Selected Readings, 1685–2000 |publisher=University of Illinois Press |isbn= 978-0-252-06999-4|page=174 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=powGjotbu9kC&printsec=frontcover&dq=I+See+America+Dancing:+Selected+Readings,+1685-2000&q}} Duncan divorced the bare foot from perceptions of obscenity and made a conscious effort to link barefoot dancing to ideals such as "nudity, childhood, the idyllic past, flowing lines, health, nobility, ease, freedom, simplicity, order, and harmony". She believed her utopian dance vision and program would ameliorate the perceived ills of modern life and restore the world to the imagined perfection of Ancient Greece. The 1954 film ''[[The Barefoot Contessa]]'' tells the fictional story of Maria Vargas (portrayed by [[Ava Gardner]]), a Spanish [[cabaret]] dancer of simple origins who frequently went barefoot. She was cast in a movie by writer and director Harry Dawes (portrayed by [[Humphrey Bogart]]) and became a major star. In 1978, [[Ina Garten]] purchased a specialty food store in [[The Hamptons]] named ''[[Barefoot Contessa]]'', after the movie. She liked the name because it went well with her simple and elegant cooking style. She sold the store in 1999 and wrote her first book, ''The Barefoot Contessa Cookbook'', which became one of the best-selling cookbooks of the year. She would go on to write more cookbooks and, in 2002, started production of a television show on the [[Food Network]], also named the ''Barefoot Contessa'', which continues to run.{{cite web|title=Ina Garten (biography)|url=http://www.foodnetwork.com/chefs/ina-garten/index.html|publisher=[[Food Network]]|accessdate=July 10, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100630134851/http://www.foodnetwork.com/chefs/ina-garten/index.html| archivedate= 30 June 2010 | deadurl= no}} [[File:Joss Stone 08 (8132151434).jpg|thumb|upright|Singer [[Joss Stone]] performing barefoot on stage]] In the latter half of the 20th century, many singers, primarily females, have performed barefoot, a trend that continues in the early 21st century. One of the first singers to become well known for singing barefoot on stage was [[Sandie Shaw]], who became known as the "Barefoot Pop Princess of the 1960s."{{cite book|last=Roberts |first=David|title=British Hit Singles & Albums|edition=19th|year=2006|location=London|publisher= Guinness World Records Limited|isbn=1-904994-10-5|page=495|url=https://books.google.com/?id=5fZvPwAACAAJ&dq=isbn=1904994105&cd=1}} [[Jimmy Buffett]] is known for performing barefoot at concerts, promoting an island/beach bum lifestyle.{{cite news|last=Carter |first=Lauren |title=Jimmy Buffett a god to lei persons |url=http://news.bostonherald.com/entertainment/music/general/view/20100619jimmy_buffett_a_god_to_lei_persons/srvc=home&position=also |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627125640/http://news.bostonherald.com/entertainment/music/general/view/20100619jimmy_buffett_a_god_to_lei_persons/srvc%3Dhome%26position%3Dalso |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 27, 2010 |accessdate=July 1, 2010 |newspaper=[[Boston Herald|The Edge]] |date=June 19, 2010 }} [[Cesária Évora]] of [[Cape Verde]] was known as the "Barefoot Diva" for her habit of performing without shoes.{{cite news|title=French honour for 'barefoot diva' |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7879515.stm|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=February 9, 2009}} Other performers known for performing barefoot onstage or in music videos include [[Ian Gillan]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/ski/interviews/Deep-Purple-interview/|title=Deep Purple: On the chairlift with...|last=English|first=Neil|date=2016-02-04|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}, [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Patti LaBelle]], [[Joss Stone]], [[Shakira]],{{cite news|title=Shakira's barefoot stage demands|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/people/news/article_1253048.php/Shakira_s_barefoot_stage_demands|accessdate=July 10, 2010|newspaper=[[Monsters and Critics]]|date=January 29, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100724153854/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/people/news/article_1253048.php/Shakira_s_barefoot_stage_demands| archivedate= 24 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} [[Steven Wilson]], [[Björk]], [[Katharine McPhee]], [[Sophie B. Hawkins]], [[Deana Carter]], [[Kelly Clarkson]], [[Florence Welch]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]], [[Dolores O'Riordan]]{{Cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3965575/remembering-dolores-oriordan-the-cranberries/|title=Alan Cross: Remembering Dolores O’Riordan, the tiny Irish woman with a big, big voice|work=Global News|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en}}, [[Emmelie de Forest]]{{Cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/participant/emmelie-de-forest|title=Emmelie de Forest - Eurovision Song Contest Tel Aviv 2019|website=eurovision.tv|access-date=2018-09-19}} and [[Gwen Stefani]].{{cite news|last=Brescia|first=Joe|title=Noticed; Barefoot Road To Glory|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/25/style/noticed-barefoot-road-to-glory.html|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=January 25, 1998}} All members of the German [[Brass instrument|brass]] [[Punk rock|punk]] band [[LaBrassBanda]] perform barefoot and in [[Lederhosen]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.tz.de/stars/labrassbanda-barfuss-um-welt-zr-7420971.html|title=LaBrassBanda: Barfuß um die Welt|date=2017-02-21|work=|language=de}} Musician, composer, actor and comedian [[Tim Minchin]] performs his live shows barefoot, saying "I don't wear shoes cos I went barefoot one day and liked it."{{cite web|url=http://www.timminchin.com/faq/|title=FAQ|work=Tim Minchin's website|accessdate=September 20, 2015}} Some singers believe that being barefoot allows them to channel their vocal energy better – a theory based on the teachings of the [[alternative medicine]] of [[reflexology]]. Others may do so to provide a more relaxing atmosphere and to calm them down. Joss Stone says that she doesn't like wearing shoes on stage because she doesn't want to fall over.{{Cite web|url=https://www.fromthegrapevine.com/arts/5-things-you-didnt-know-about-joss-stone|title=5 things you didn't know about Joss Stone|website=From the Grapevine|language=en|access-date=2018-09-13}} [[Tony Meléndez]] and [[Mark Goffeney]] have played the [[guitar]] on stage barefoot, with their feet, since they were born with no arms.{{cite news|title=Born Without Arms, this Six-Year-Old Oklahoma Tot Finds it No Handicap|url=http://www.sideshowworld.com/tgodjoan.html|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=Bismarck Tribune|date=June 18, 1930|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712015830/http://www.sideshowworld.com/tgodjoan.html#|archivedate=2010-07-12|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite news|author=Hampson, Rick|author2=O'Driscoll, Patrick|title=Tony Melendez Wise words: 'Give hope'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2005-04-03-pope-profiles-melendez_x.htm|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=April 3, 2005}}{{cite news|title=Armed With Talent|url=http://www.abilitymagazine.com/mark-goffeney.html|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[Ability (magazine)|Ability]]|issue=February/March 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728090610/http://www.abilitymagazine.com/mark-goffeney.html|archivedate=2010-07-28|deadurl=yes|df=}} Similarly, in 2008, [[Jessica Cox]] became the first person with no arms to use her bare feet to fly an airplane.{{cite news|title=Woman Born With No Arms Becomes First Pilot to Fly Airplane With Feet|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,463368,00.html|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=Fox News|date=December 8, 2008}} There are armless artists who use their bare feet to paint, including [[Simona Atzori]], who is a dancer.{{cite web|last=Atzori|first=Simona|title=Prossimi Appuntamenti|url=http://www.simonarte.com/|publisher=Self-Published|accessdate=July 1, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100612183607/http://www.simonarte.com/| archivedate= 12 June 2010 | deadurl= no}} Renowned Scottish [[percussionist]] [[Evelyn Glennie]], who is almost completely deaf, always performs her concerts barefoot in order to feel the vibrations of her instruments and the orchestra accompanying her. ==Health implications== [[File:(Left) (B) Adult foot that has never worn shoes, (Right) (A) Foot of a boy who has worn shoes for just a few weeks. Plaster casts.jpg|thumbnail|(Left–B) plaster cast of an adult foot that has never worn shoes displaying natural splayed toes (Right–A) cast of boy showing damage and inward-turned toes after wearing shoes for only a few weeks]] There are risks and benefits associated with going barefoot. Footwear provides some protection from puncture wounds from glass, nails, rocks, or thorns as well as abrasions, bruises, heat burns, electrical shock, and [[frostbite]]—but studies of people who habitually walk barefoot have consistently found that these problems are minimal, with only about 0.89% of barefoot people having any kind of foot complaint linked to walking barefoot (including temporary conditions such as abrasions) or having the tops of the feet uncovered.{{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} Feet that have never worn shoes rarely exhibit problems such as bunions, corns, and "[[Flat feet|fallen arches]]",{{cite journal |vauthors=Rao UB, Joseph B |title=The influence of footwear on the prevalence of flat foot. A survey of 2300 children |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Br |volume=74-B |issue=4 |pages=525–27 |date=July 1992 |pmid=1624509 |issn=0301-620X}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Sachithandam V, Joseph B |title=The influence of footwear on the prevalence of flat foot. A survey of 1846 mature persons |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Br |volume=77-B |issue=2 |pages=254–57 |date=March 1995 |pmid=7706341 |issn=0301-620X}} are not prone to more than ordinary foot eversion on standing and walking due to the associated weakness or stiffness of the joints of the foot and weakness of the muscles controlling them,{{cite journal |author=Hoffmann P |title=Conclusions drawn from a comparative study of the feet of barefooted and shoe-wearing peoples |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Am |volume=2 |issue=3 |pages=105–36 |date=October 1905 | url=http://bsmpg.com/Portals/52884/docs/1905Hoffman.pdf}} as well as having a much reduced incidence of problems such as callouses.{{cite journal|last=Zipfel|first=B.|author2=L.R. Berger|title=Shod versus unshod: The emergence of forefoot pathology in modern humans?|journal=The Foot|date=17 May 2007}} Walking barefoot results in a more natural gait. People who are used to walking barefoot tend to land less forcefully, eliminating the hard heel strike and generating much less collision force in the foot and lower leg.{{cite news|last=Sternbergh |first=Adam |title=You Walk Wrong. |url=http://nymag.com/health/features/46213/ |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |newspaper=New York Magazine |date=April 21, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080422191147/http://nymag.com/health/features/46213/ |archivedate=April 22, 2008 |deadurl=no }} A 2006 study found that shoes may increase stress on the knee and ankle, and suggested that adults who walked barefoot may have a lower rate of [[osteoarthritis]],{{cite journal |vauthors=Shakoor N, Block JA |title=Walking barefoot decreases loading on the lower extremity joints in knee osteoarthritis |journal=Arthritis Rheum. |volume=54 |issue=9 |pages=2923–27 |year=2006 |pmid=16947448 |doi=10.1002/art.22123 |ref=harv}} although more study is required to elucidate the factors that distribute loads in shod and barefoot walking. A 2007 study examined 180 modern humans and compared their feet with 2,000-year-old skeletons. They concluded that, before the invention of shoes, humans overall had healthier feet. A 1991 study found that children who wore shoes were three times more likely to have [[flat feet]] than those who did not, and suggested that wearing shoes in early childhood can be detrimental to the longitudinal arch of the foot. Children who habitually go barefoot were found to have stronger feet, with better flexibility and mobility, fewer deformities like flat feet or toes that curve inwards, and fewer complaints.{{cite news|last=Angier|first=Natalie|title=Which Shoes Are Best For Children? Maybe None.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/14/news/which-shoes-are-best-for-children-maybe-none.html|accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 14, 1991}} Walking barefoot enables a more natural gait, eliminating the hard heel strike and instead, allowing for a rocking motion of the foot from heel to toe. Similarly, barefoot running usually involves an initial forefoot strike, instead of on the rear of the foot, generating smaller collision forces. Since there is no artificial protection of the bare foot, some of the possible issues include cuts, abrasions, bruises, or puncture wounds from glass, nails, rocks, or thorns, as well as poisonous plants, animals, or [[parasite]]s that can enter the body through the cuts on an injured bare foot.{{cite journal |author=Staheli LT |title=Shoes for children: a review |journal=Pediatrics |volume=88 |issue=2 |pages=371–75 |year=1991 |pmid=1861942 |doi= |ref=harv}} In people who are not habitually barefoot, [[Athlete's foot]] is spread by fungal spores coming into contact with skin that has been weakened and made moist. The fungus is known to only affect around 0.75% of habitually barefoot people in one study and can be prevented by reducing shoe use and keeping the feet dry, particularly after walking through a damp environment where people communally walk barefoot as the fungus only develops under the right conditions, such as when people fail to properly dry their feet after swimming or showering and then put on shoes. Wearing shoes such as flip flops or sandals in these areas can reduce the risk.{{cite web|last=Hyde|first=Patricia|title=Athlete's Foot|url=http://kidshealth.org/kid/health_problems/skin/athletes_foot.html|publisher=kidshealth.org|accessdate=July 1, 2010}} As such, the fungus is very unlikely to develop on a person who goes barefoot all the time. The [[hookworm]] parasite, found only in warm, moist climates where human [[feces]] contaminated with hookworm larvae has been left in places where it might come into contact with human skin, can burrow through a bare human foot (or any part of the body that comes into contact with it).{{cite news|url=https://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/hookworm/factsht_hookworm.htm |title=Hookworm Infection |date=September 11, 2008 |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] |accessdate=August 4, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000301095412/http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dpd/parasites/hookworm/factsht_hookworm.htm |archivedate=March 1, 2000 |deadurl=no }} However, as the parasite tends to occur mainly in mud and cesspools, its spread cannot be stopped by most standard shoes{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} since the larvae can penetrate fabric and small holes. The parasite may spread through contaminated material coming into contact with any part of the body, such as through flecks of mud splashing on an ankle or leg.{{cite journal|last=Trop|first=Am J|title=Penetration by Infective Hookworm Larvae of the Materials Used in the Manufacture of Shoes|url=http://www.ajtmh.org/content/s1-9/1/79.citation|accessdate=26 October 2012}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The [[hookworm]] parasite is relatively mild, has few symptoms, and can pass completely unnoticed when the infestation level is low enough. Since the hookworm infection is very cheap and easy to treat, and since it requires infected feces to come into contact with human skin within a particular time period, eradicating hookworm is mainly a matter of hygiene (including the building of proper toilet and waste-disposal facilities) and mass-treatment. In very cold weather, shoes can provide thermal insulation, protecting against [[frostbite]]. Issues that can develop as a result of someone who has always worn shoes going barefoot include calf pain or [[Achilles tendinitis]] or [[plantar fasciitis]] due to shortening of the Achilles tendon and the foot being underdeveloped, due to regular use of shoes. A careful transition ease or remove symptoms, which quickly vanish as the foot adapts.{{cite web|last=Quinn|first=Elizabeth|title=Barefoot Running – The Pros and Cons of Going Shoeless|url=http://sportsmedicine.about.com/od/runningworkouts/a/Barefoot-Running.htm|publisher=About.com|accessdate=June 26, 2010}}{{cite book|last=Howell|first=Daniel|title=The Barefoot Book|year=2010|publisher=Hunter House|isbn= 978-1630266639}} Blisters on the feet may occur in the first few weeks of going barefoot, until the skin has become more robust. Individuals with [[diabetes]] or other conditions that affect sensation in the feet are at greater risk of injury while barefoot. The [[American Diabetes Association]] recommends that diabetics wear shoes and socks at all times.{{cite web|title=Foot Care. |url=http://www.diabetes.org/living-with-diabetes/complications/foot-complications/foot-care.html |publisher=[[American Diabetes Association]] |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107213834/http://www.diabetes.org/living-with-diabetes/complications/foot-complications/foot-care.html |archivedate=November 7, 2011 |deadurl=no }} == Laws == In the United States, there have been myths that regulations require the wearing of footwear. In the United States, during the period of the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture movement of the 1960s]], business establishments would deny admittance to barefoot [[hippie]]s arguing that health regulations required that shoes be worn.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/1088537.html |title=Going barefoot |last=Miller |first=Joe |date=May 29, 2008 |work=[[The News and Observer]] |accessdate=August 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602011040/http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/1088537.html |archivedate=June 2, 2008 }} This led to a belief by many in nonexistent [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] or local health department regulations preventing people from going to stores, restaurants, and other establishments without shoes. However, those regulations that exist apply only to employees and not customers.{{cite web|url=http://www.barefooters.org/osha.html |title=Bare Feet and OSHA |date=January 7, 2006 |publisher=barefooters.org |accessdate=August 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090524040917/http://barefooters.org/osha.html |archivedate=May 24, 2009 |df= }} Specifically, the United States [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] requires employers to "ensure that each affected employee uses protective footwear" when there is a danger of foot injuries due to falling or rolling objects, objects piercing the sole of an employee's foot, and where an employee's feet may be exposed to electrical hazards.{{cite news|last=Chow |first=Andrew |title=Is Going Barefoot at Work a Step Too Far? |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/02/tagblogsfindlawcom2012-freeenterprise-idUS286283164820120502 |accessdate=May 2, 2012 |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=May 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508074700/http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/05/02/tagblogsfindlawcom2012-freeenterprise-idUS286283164820120502 |archivedate=May 8, 2012 |df= }} Additionally, employee footwear, where required by OSHA, must comply with one of the standards described in OSHA's regulations. State and local laws may dictate when and where an employee must wear shoes. Some people speculate that driving barefoot increases the risk of an accident if bare feet slip off the pedals.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/1088537.html |title=Legal myths, rumors about driving barefoot busted |last=Lawson |first=Alex |date=September 6, 2007 |work=[[The Daily Vidette]] |accessdate=August 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602011040/http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/1088537.html |archivedate=June 2, 2008 }} It is legal throughout the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom to drive barefoot.{{cite web|url=http://www.barefooters.org/faq/18.html |title=Q18: Is it legal to drive barefoot? |date=July 13, 2004 |publisher=barefooters.org |accessdate=August 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430105112/http://www.barefooters.org/faq/18.html |archivedate=April 30, 2009 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/driving-california-shoes-2027147-vehicle-barefoot|title=HONK: The myth about driving barefoot|last=Hernandez|first=Salvador|date=April 25, 2008|work=|accessdate=August 5, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907062322/http://www.ocregister.com/news/driving-181942-california-shoes.html|archive-date=2015-09-07|dead-url=yes|publisher=''[[The Orange County Register]]''}} However, in some US jurisdictions, police officers may ticket a driver for other things if the fact that they were driving barefoot or in [[flip-flops]]/high heeled shoes hindered their driving and/or resulted in an accident.{{cite web|url=http://www.barefooters.org/driving/index.html |title=Definitive Answer to Driving Barefoot in America |accessdate=15 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222034855/http://www.barefooters.org/driving/index.html |archivedate=22 February 2014 |df= }} ==Sports and recreation== [[File:Blue leggings.jpg|thumb|right|A woman sitting in a library with her bare feet on a chair.]] There are several recreational activities one can participate in while barefoot. Those involved in [[water sports]] such as [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]] and [[water polo]] almost always participate barefoot due to the difficulty of swimming with footwear. Other common activities performed barefoot include yoga, pilates, [[hiking]], running, driving, water skiing, [[touch rugby]], [[soccer]], [[beach volleyball]], [[surfing]], [[tubing (recreation)|tubing]], [[gymnastics]], [[Slacklining]], and [[martial arts]]. [[Wrestling]] can be done barefoot. Although most modern [[Greco-Roman wrestling|Greco-Roman]] and [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] wrestlers wear shoes, [[sumo wrestling]], [[Yağlı güreş]] (oil or "Turkish" wrestling), and [[mud wrestling]] are commonly done while barefoot. [[Fiji]]an wrestler [[Jimmy Snuka|Jimmy "Superfly" Snuka]] of the WWE has wrestled barefoot as well.{{cite news|last=Traina |first=Jimmy |title=Favorite Wrestlers of All Time |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/si_blogs/scorecard/jimmys_blog/2006/06/favorite-wrestlers-of-all-time.html |accessdate=July 10, 2010 |newspaper=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=June 12, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080407185431/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/si_blogs/scorecard/jimmys_blog/2006/06/favorite-wrestlers-of-all-time.html |archivedate=April 7, 2008 |df= }} [[American football]] is not traditionally a barefoot sport, though several [[placekicker]]s have preferred to kick barefoot, including [[Tony Franklin (kicker)|Tony Franklin]] of the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] and [[Rich Karlis]] of the [[Denver Broncos]].{{cite news|last=Gehman|first=Jim|title=Where Are They Now: PK Tony Franklin|url=http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/Story.asp?story_id=12521|accessdate=June 27, 2010|newspaper=[[Philadelphia Eagles]]|date=May 5, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100619135621/http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/Story.asp?story_id=12521| archivedate= 19 June 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Moss|first=Irv|title=Karlis a standout as barefoot kicker|url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_11559948?source=bb|accessdate=June 27, 2010|newspaper=[[Denver Post]]|date=January 27, 2009}} The two schools of thought involved in barefoot placekicking were that the lack of a shoe provided the kicker with a better "feel" for the ball and greater control over its trajectory. The second theory is that shoes and socks absorbed kinetic energy, and kicking flesh-to-leather created more [[torque]].{{cite news|last=Klosterman|first=Chuck|title=A brilliant idea! (For now)|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=klosterman/061016 |accessdate=June 27, 2010|newspaper=ESPN|date=October 16, 2006}} ===Hiking=== People of all ages all over the world can participate in barefoot hiking, gathering for walks through forest and hiking trails sans footwear. Barefoot hikers claim that they feel a sense of communion with the earth and enjoy the sheer pleasure of feeling more of the world with their feet.{{cite news|last=Todras-Whitehill|first=Ethan|title=Footloose and Boot Free: Barefoot Hiking.|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/2006/09/22/travel/escapes/22hike.html|accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 22, 2006}} There are several clubs throughout North America practicing regular barefoot hikes, including the Barefoot Hikers of Minnesota, Seattle Barefoot Hikers, East Bay Barefoot Hikers, the Barefoot Hikers and Grass Walkers of Greater Kansas City, and the Barefoot Hikers of Connecticut.{{cite news|last=Pauly |first=Brett |title=Sole Survivors: New shoeless joes are hitting dusty trails around San Francisco Bay and beyond. |url=http://barefooters.org/hikers/publicity/la_daily_news.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19961029205731/http://www.barefooters.org/hikers/publicity/la_daily_news.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 29, 1996 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |newspaper=Los Angeles Daily News |date=March 21, 1996 }}{{cite web|title=Barefoot Hiking Groups|url=http://www.barefoothub.com/barefoot-hiking-groups/|website=The Barefoot Hub|accessdate=16 April 2015}} In this an [[analogy]] to the [[social state]] of former slaves was established, who were regularly forced to remain barefoot as well (see above).{{cite news|last=Lanza |first=Michael |title=The Happy Hoofers |url=http://barefooters.org/hikers/publicity/yankee.txt |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/19961029205838/http://www.barefooters.org/hikers/publicity/yankee.txt |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1996-10-29 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |newspaper=Yankee Magazine |date=July 1995 }}{{cite news|title=In Conn. barefoot hiking club, tenderfoots welcome|url=http://www.courant.com/community/county-new-haven/hc-ap-ct-fea-barefoothikinjun19,0,5048908.story|accessdate=June 28, 2010|newspaper=Hartford Courant|date=June 20, 2010}}{{dead link|date=September 2016}} Two sisters, Lucy and Susan Letcher, hiked approximately two-thirds of the {{convert|2,175|mi|km|adj=on}} [[Appalachian Trail]] barefoot from June 21, 2000, to October 3, 2001.{{cite news|last=Belisle |first=Richard F. |title=Barefoot hikers return to Appalachian Trail for book tour |url=http://www.herald-mail.com/?cmd=displaystory&story_id=228195&format=html |accessdate=June 28, 2010 |newspaper=The Herald-Mail |date=August 5, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hXOgrXpN?url=http://www.herald-mail.com/?cmd=displaystory |archivedate=June 15, 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite book|title=The Barefoot Sisters: Southbound|year=2009|publisher=Stackpole Books|isbn=0-8117-3530-3|page=474|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_cFbPQAACAAJ&dq=barefoot+sisters|author8=Letcher, Lucy; Letcher, Susan}} On November 12, 2010, 2,500 people in [[Mahabubnagar]], [[India]], participated in a barefoot walk, which was recognized by ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' as the world's largest.{{cite web|title=Largest Barefoot Walk |url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/8000/largest-barefoot-walk|publisher=[[Guinness World Records]] |accessdate=July 16, 2012}} In European nations, including Austria, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom, there are barefoot parks or walks.{{cite news|last=Owen|first=Wena Alun|title=Challenge senses on barefoot walk. |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/north_west/7955356.stm|accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=March 20, 2009}}{{cite web|title=Public Barefoot Parks in Europe.|url=http://www.barfusspark.info/en/park.htm|publisher=barfusspark.info|accessdate=June 26, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100605081950/http://www.barfusspark.info/en/park.htm| archivedate= 5 June 2010 | deadurl= no}} These parks are kept clean and maintained on a regular basis, so that barefoot hiking can be done in an environment suitable for people who are habitually shod. Barefoot parks usually include a lot of adventure stations, allowing visitors to experience the feeling of soil textures underfoot; to wade through rivers, mud, brooks, or ponds; and to exercise [[foot gymnastics]], [[Equilibrioception|balancing]], and climbing. The ''Barfußpfad'' (barefoot trail) at Bad Sobernheim in Germany attracts over 100,000 visitors annually and has seen approximately 1 million visitors since its inception in 1999.{{cite news|title=Fast eine Million Menschen.|url=http://www.allgemeine-zeitung.de/region/bad-kreuznach-bad-sobernheim-kirn/vg-bad-sobernheim/sobernheim/7927509.htm|accessdate=June 26, 2010|newspaper=Allgemeine Beitung |date=November 25, 2009|language=German}} This concept was first developed in the 19th century by [[Sebastian Kneipp]], one of the founders of the [[Naturopathy|Naturopathic medicine]] movement. He believed that applying your feet to a range of natural stimuli would have therapeutic benefits. This is related to the ancient practice of [[reflexology]], practiced in China for thousands of years for relaxation and to promote longevity.{{cite news|last=Wignall|first=Alice|title=Get your socks off|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2008/mar/25/healthandwellbeing.walkingholidays|accessdate=July 1, 2010|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=March 25, 2008}} [[Seoul]], South Korea, has 158 barefoot parks, allowing people to relax in a natural environment.{{cite news|title=158 barefoot parks in Seoul |url=http://english.seoul.go.kr/gtk/news/news_view.php?idx=413 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130218204705/http://english.seoul.go.kr/gtk/news/news_view.php?idx=413 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 18, 2013 |accessdate=June 26, 2010 |newspaper=seoul.go.kr |date=May 12, 2006 }} ===Running=== {{main|Barefoot running}} Many leisure and competitive runners have been known to run barefoot, including well-known athletes [[Zola Budd]] of South Africa and [[Abebe Bikila]] of [[Ethiopia]].{{cite journal|last=Warburton|first=Michael |title=Barefoot Running |journal=Sportscience|date=Sep–Dec 2001|volume=5|issue=3 |url=http://sportsci.org/jour/0103/mw.htm|accessdate=June 27, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100722064341/http://www.sportsci.org/jour/0103/mw.htm| archivedate= 22 July 2010 | deadurl= no}} Todd Ragsdale, of [[Talent, Oregon]], set the world record (pending confirmation by ''[[Guinness World Records]]'') for the longest distance run barefoot on June 5, 2010, as part of the [[Relay for Life]] fundraiser for the [[American Cancer Society]]. He logged {{convert|102|mi|km}}, or 413 laps on the South Medford High School track, barefoot.{{cite news|last=Burke |first=Anita |title=Todd Ragsdale endures The agony of the feet |url=http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100608/NEWS/6080317/-1/NEWSMAP |accessdate=July 1, 2010 |newspaper=[[Mail Tribune]] |date=June 8, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610195008/http://www.mailtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100608%2FNEWS%2F6080317%2F-1%2FNEWSMAP |archivedate=10 June 2010 |deadurl=no }} The fastest person to run 100 meters (325 feet) on [[ice]] while barefoot is Nico Surings of [[Eindhoven]], Netherlands, who ran that distance in 17.35 seconds on December 8, 2006.{{cite web|title=Fastest run 100 metres barefoot on ice|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records/amazing_feats/unusual_skills/Fastest_run_100_metres_barefoot_on_ice.aspx|publisher=[[Guinness World Records]]|accessdate=July 1, 2010}} Laboratory studies suggest that, due to the lack of extra weight on the feet, the energy cost of running barefoot is reduced by 4%, resulting in lower [[oxygen]] consumption. There is evidence that wearing traditional shoes while running leads to heel strike [[Gait (human)|gait]] that, in turn, leads to higher impact as well as a greater risk of injury. Barefoot running encourages the runner to switch to forefoot strike and may reduce the risk of knee damage. Barefoot running can be dangerous, especially to runners who do not adequately prepare or give their feet time to adapt to the new style. Many injuries are possible, such as injuries to the [[Achilles tendon]] or [[plantar fascia]], or [[stress fracture]]s in the [[metatarsal]] bones or lower leg.
