revision.text:
[[File:Jean Louis Théodore Géricault 005.jpg|right|300px|thumb|''Mazeppa'' by [[Théodore Géricault]] ca. 1823; based on Byron's poem.]]
*''The spelling "Mazepa" refers to the historical person; the double-p "Mazeppa" is used for the artistic and literary works.''
[[Ivan Stepanovych Mazepa|Ivan Mazepa]] (1639–1709) was a significant figure in the [[history of Ukraine]]. One story about him says that as a young man, he was caught ''[[in flagrante]]'' with a noblewoman, whose husband punished him by tying him naked to a wild horse and setting them free; eventually he reached the Cossacks and became their military leader. This caught the attention of the English poet [[Lord Byron]] ("[[Lady Caroline Lamb#Lord Byron|mad, bad, and dangerous to know]]"), whose ''[[Mazeppa (poem)|Mazeppa]]'' (1819) brought the events to wider attention. His [[narrative poem]] inspired many paintings, particularly by French Romantics, which in turn stimulated musical compositions, stage plays, more poems, and so on. New life was breathed into the equestrian tale when it was transposed to the American [[Wild West]].
==The historical figure== {{Main|Ivan Mazepa}} Mazepa served as [[Hetman of Zaporizhian Host]] in 1687–1708. He played an important role in the [[Battle of Poltava]] (1709), where after learning that the Russian Tsar, [[Peter the Great]], intended to replace him with [[Alexander Danilovich Menshikov|Alexander Menshikov]], he deserted his army and sided with King [[Charles XII of Sweden]]. The political consequences and interpretation of this desertion have resonated in the national histories both of Russia and of Ukraine. The alienation of Mazepa from Ukrainian historiography continued during the Soviet period, but post-1991 in independent Ukraine there have been strong moves to rehabilitate Mazepa's image, although he remains a controversial figure.
==Byron's poem== {{Main|Mazeppa (poem)}} [[File:Mazeppa - Byron.png|thumb|right|300px|Currier and Ives illustration to their 1846 printing of the poem]] [[Lord Byron]] published his [[narrative poetry|narrative poem]] in 1819. According to the poem, the young Mazeppa has a love affair with a Polish Countess Theresa while serving as a page at the Court of King [[John II Casimir Vasa]]. Countess Theresa was married to a much older Count. On discovering the affair, the Count punishes Mazeppa by tying him naked to a wild horse and setting the horse loose. The bulk of the poem describes the traumatic journey of the hero strapped to the horse. The poem has been praised for its "vigor of style and its sharp realization of the feelings of suffering and endurance".<ref name="Marchand">{{cite book|last=Marchand|first=Leslie|date=1968|title=Byron's Poetry: A Critical Introduction|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|page=70}}</ref>
There is no historical evidence to support that Mazepa was exiled from Poland because of a love affair, or that he was punished by being strapped to a wild horse.<ref>{{cite book|last=Blumberg|first=Arnold|date=1995|title=Great Leaders, Great Tyrants?|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|location=Santa Barbara, CA|pages=184–88}}</ref> However, this colorful legend was in circulation before Byron published his poem. [[Voltaire]] repeats it in ''History of Charles XII, King of Sweden'' (1731). This appears to have been Byron's main source for his poem: his 'Advertisement' to the poem includes three long quotations from this work. Several critics have also speculated that Byron was familiar with the ''Mémoires d'Azéma'' (1764) by the French writer [[André Guillaume Contant Dorville]], as there are significant similarities between the plot of that novel and of Byron's poem.<ref name="Babinski">{{cite book|last=Babinski|first=H.F.|date=1975|title=The Mazeppa legend in European Romanticism|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|pages=28–32}}</ref>
==The first wave of reaction== [[File:Mazeppa Louis Boulanger.jpg|thumb|Louis Boulanger, ''Mazeppa'']] Byron's poem was both popular and influential in the [[Romanticism|Romantic period]]. [[Horses in art]] had long been a popular theme, so when the poem was translated into French the same year by [[Amédée Pichot]], a wave of French painters decided to depict Mazeppa's "wild ride", including [[Théodore Géricault]] (1823, now held in the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Théodore Gericault {{!}} Mazeppa {{!}} The Met|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/358010|website=The Metropolitan Museum of Art, i.e. The Met Museum|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref>), [[Eugène Delacroix]] (1824, [[Finnish National Gallery]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Finnish National Gallery - Art Collections - Mazeppa on the Dying Horse|url=http://kokoelmat.fng.fi/app?si=A+II+1426&lang=en|website=Finnish National Gallery - Art Collections|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref>), [[Horace Vernet]] (1826, [[Musée Calvet]] in Avignon<ref>{{cite web|title=Présentation du musée - ANGLAIS - MUSEUM ROOMS - upstairs 1|url=http://www.musee-calvet-avignon.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=815|website=www.musee-calvet-avignon.com|accessdate=24 April 2018|language=fr-fr}}</ref>), and [[Louis Boulanger]] (1827, the [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Rouen]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Ordeal of Mazeppa|url=http://mbarouen.fr/en/oeuvres/the-ordeal-of-mazeppa|website=Musée des Beaux-Arts|accessdate=24 April 2018|language=fr|date=30 May 2013}}</ref>). Boulanger's ''The Ordeal of Mazeppa'' and Vernet's ''Mazeppa and the Wolves'' both competed in the [[Salon (Paris)|Salon of 1827]]{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}.
A theatrical version of the story soon appeared: a show called ''Mazeppa, or the Tartar Horse'' premiered at [[Antonio Franconi]]'s [[Cirque Olympique]] in Paris in 1825. This was copied in both the USA and England.<ref name="Mainardi"/> [[Aleksandr Pushkin]] wrote a poem-response to Byron entitled ''[[Poltava (poem)|Poltava]]'' (1828–29), which opens with an epigraph from the Englishman's poem, and in which he portrays Mazeppa as a villain who betrayed Russians.
[[Victor Hugo]] was inspired by the French Romantic paintings to compose "Mazeppa", one of the major pieces in ''[[Les Orientales]]'' (1829), which he dedicated to Boulanger. The first part of his poem describes Mazeppa's run across Ukrainian plains. The second part compares Mazeppa to a poet banned from the living world because of his eccentricities, the banned poet is attached to the wild horse of his inspiration. The comparison to the poet ends by saying that this crazy trip through suffering finally gives success and glory to the poet.
==The 1830s-1860s== [[Image:Astley's Amphitheatre Microcosm edited.jpg|thumb|A similar equestrian show at [[Astley's Amphitheatre]] in London]] [[File:Théodore Chassériau 005.jpg|thumb|Théodore Chassériau, ''Cossack girl at Mazeppa's body'']]
The playwright [[Henry M. Milner]] wrote ''Mazeppa; or, The wild horse of Tartary. A romantic drama, in three acts. Dramatised from Lord Byron's poem by H.M. Milner, and adapted to the stage under the direction of Mr. Ducrow.''<ref>OCLC 31254994</ref> (This was [[Andrew Ducrow]], the "Father of British circus [[equestrianism]]" and proprietor of [[Astley's Amphitheatre]].) It appeared in London in 1831. Over the next several years it toured the US, until "at one point, five different productions of the play were showing in San Francisco".<ref name="University of Oklahoma Press">{{cite book|last1=Fisher|first1=Linda A.|last2=Bowers|first2=Carrie|title=Agnes Lake Hickok : queen of the circus, wife of a legend|date=2009|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman|isbn=9780806139838|chapter=7: Mazeppa Enters the Ring}}</ref>
[[John Frederick Herring Sr.]], an Englishman who started out as a stagecoach driver, painted several versions of the story: two are "after Horace Vernet" (circa 1833, [[Tate]]<ref>{{cite web|title=‘Mazeppa Surrounded by Horses (after Horace Vernet)’, John Frederick Herring, c.1833 {{!}} Tate|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/herring-mazeppa-surrounded-by-horses-after-horace-vernet-t00189|website=Tate|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=‘Mazeppa Pursued by Wolves (after Horace Vernet)’, John Frederick Herring, 1833 {{!}} Tate|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/herring-mazeppa-pursued-by-wolves-after-horace-vernet-t00188|website=Tate|accessdate=24 April 2018}}</ref> and in 1842 "MAZEPPA"{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}. In 1846, the American lithographer [[Nathaniel Currier]], of [[Currier and Ives]], prepared four plates, with Byronic quotations; the artworks are now at [[Bridgeman Art Library]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Boime|first=Albert|date=1993|title=Art in an age of Bonapartism, 1800–1815|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|pages=170–1}}</ref><ref name="Mainardi">{{cite book|last=Mainardi|first=Patricia|date=2003|title= Husbands, Wives and Lovers: Marriage and its Discontents in Nineteenth-Century France|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven|chapter=6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Conningham|first1=Frederic A.|title=Currier and Ives prints : an illustrated check list.|date=1983|publisher=Crown Publ.|location=New York|isbn=9780517551158|page=36|edition= New, updated}}</ref>
[[Juliusz Słowacki]], a major figure in the [[Romanticism in Poland|Polish Romantic period]], wrote a play entitled ''Mazeppa'' (1840). Although he is now considered the father of modern Polish drama, it was the only one of his dramas that was put on stage during his lifetime.<ref>Christopher John Murray (2004). Encyclopedia of the romantic era, 1760–1850. Taylor & Francis. pp. 1059–61. {{ISBN|978-1-57958-423-8}}.</ref> [[James Malcolm Rymer]], a British writer of [[penny dreadful]]s, wrote ''Mazeppa; or, The Wild Horse of the Ukraine: A Romance'' (1850).
Musicians were also inspired. [[Carl Loewe]] composed a tone-poem.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mazeppa - A Tone-Poem after Byron, Op. 27 - Carl Loewe & Linda Nicholson Song - BBC Music|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/tracks/n5z298|website=BBC|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref> A generation after Hugo published his poem, it became the literary inspiration for [[Mazeppa (symphonic poem)|a symphonic poem]] (1851) and [[Transcendental Étude No. 4 (Liszt)|a Transcendental Étude]] (1852) by [[Franz Liszt]]. Another French Romantic painter, [[Théodore Chassériau]], re-interpreted Byron's poem, with ''Cossack girl at Mazeppa 's body'' (1851, [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Une jeune fille cosaque trouve Mazeppa évanoui sur le cheval sauvage - Musées de Strasbourg|url=https://www.musees.strasbourg.eu/oeuvre-musee-des-beaux-arts/-/entity/id/220490|website=www.musees.strasbourg.eu|accessdate=24 April 2018|language=fr-FR}}</ref>). The Irishman [[Michael William Balfe]] composed a [[cantata]] known as ''The Page'' or ''Mazeppa'' in 1861.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Barrett|first1=William Alexander|title=Balfe:His Life and Work|date=1882|page=244|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>
Milner's play was adapted and [[burlesque]]d over the decades. For example, in 1856 it was re-written as an equestrian burlesque in two acts, by [[blackface]] minstrel entertainer [[Charles "Charlie" White]]. The main antagonist is Castiron, and his daughter is Olinska.<ref>{{cite book|title=Contested Interpretations of the Past in Polish, Russian, and Ukrainian Film: Screen as Battlefield|page=149|accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref> The Mazeppa story became "a well-worn melodrama in dire need of revitalization", which it received from the performer [[Adah Isaacs Menken]]. Other women had played Mazeppa, including [[Charlotte Cushman]], but Menken's interpretation -- "sexing up" the part, scandalously performing the nude scene clad only in a flesh-colored [[bodystocking]]—really caught the public imagination.<ref name="University of Oklahoma Press"/> Many other female Mazeppas followed,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Slout|first1=William L.|title=En Route to the Great Eastern Circus and Other Essays on Circus History|date=2016|isbn= 978-1-4344-3547-7|page=54}}</ref> as did a new wave of burlesques. ''Mazeppa'' was very popular during the [[American Civil War]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sentilles|first1=Renée M.|title=Performing Menken : Adah Isaacs Menken and the birth of American celebrity|date=2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780521820707|page=94}}</ref> and became the most widely performed drama in the [[American west]] from the 1860s until the turn of the century,{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} and was also popular in London.<ref>{{cite book|last=Stedman|first=Jane W.|date=2000|title=W.S. Gilbert's Theatrical Criticism|publisher=The Society for Theatre Research|location=Sheffield}}</ref>
[[Agnes Thatcher Lake]], a [[circus]] performer and equestrian all her life, took a production of ''Mazeppa'' to Europe in 1865, performing before [[Prince Friedrich Karl of Prussia (1828–85)|Prince Karl of Prussia]]. She then took her production across the United States, the only circus to do so, performing under her company's big top tents in towns and cities without a theatre big enough to host a stage show. A 2009 biography of Lake (who later married [[Wild Bill Hickok]]) estimates that two million Americans saw her athletic interpretation of Mazeppa, many more than saw Menken's sexualised one .<ref name="University of Oklahoma Press"/>
==The 1870s-1880s== In 1877, Albert Aiken wrote a [[dime novel]] called ''The Indian Mazeppa or The Madman of the Plains'', in which the myth is transposed to the [[Wild West]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ivan Mazeppa|website=University of Manitoba|url=http://umanitoba.ca/centres/ukrainian_canadian/ucco/indianmazeppa.html|accessdate=14 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212231107/http://umanitoba.ca/centres/ukrainian_canadian/ucco/indianmazeppa.html|archivedate=12 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Pushkin's poem became the subject of [[Mazeppa (opera)|an opera entitled ''Mazeppa'']], written between 1881 and 1883, with three acts and six scenes. The music is by [[Tchaikovsky]] and the libretto by [[Victor Burenin]]. It is set in Ukraine in the 18th century, and is a story about love, abduction, political persecution and vengeful murder.
In 1910, [[Francis Boggs]] produced a short film based on the stage play of Byron's poem titled ''Mazeppa or the Wild horse of Tartary''.<ref>{{IMDb title | 0001311 | Mazeppa or the Wild horse of Tartary }}</ref>
==Since 1990==
In 1991, [[Declaration of Independence of Ukraine|Ukraine declared independence]], and Mazeppa rose again in international consciousness. A French [[drama film]] titled ''[[Mazeppa (film)|Mazeppa]]'', based loosely on the lives of the painter Géricault and the equestrian Franconi, won a prize at the [[1993 Cannes Film Festival]].<ref name="festival-cannes.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/2565/year/1993.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Mazeppa |accessdate=2009-08-22|work=festival-cannes.com}}</ref> Gericault decided to stay and live with the circus and painted only horses to try and understand the mystery of this animal; Mazeppa embodies a man carried away by his passion.
A Ukrainian film by [[Yuri Ilyenko]] loosely based on historical facts, called ''[[A Prayer for Hetman Mazepa (film)|A Prayer for Hetman Mazepa]]'' was released in 2002.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0323279/ Molitva za getmana Mazepu (2002)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
A South African interpretation of the Mazepa-Mazeppa motif describes it as "Romantic Phaethon" ([[Phaethon|a character in Greek mythology]] who drove the sun-chariot too recklessly) and points to its appeal to [[Modernist poetry|Modernist poets]] such as [[Bertol Brecht]] and [[Roy Campbell (poet)|Roy Campbell]].<ref>VOSS, Tony. Mazeppa-Maseppa: migration of a Romantic motifMazeppa-Maseppa: migration of a Romantic motif. Tydskr. letterkd. [online]. 2012, vol.49, n.2 [cited 2018-04-25], pp.110-135. Available from: <http://www.scielo.org.za/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0041-476X2012000200009&lng=en&nrm=iso>. ISSN 2309-9070.</ref>
==References== {{reflist|group=nb}}
[[Category:Cultural history of Ukraine]] [[Category:Romantic art]] [[Category:Narrative poems]] [[Category:Ivan Mazepa]] [[Category:Lord Byron]] [[Category:Victor Hugo]] [[Category:Franz Liszt]] [[Category:Alexander Pushkin]] [[Category:Horses in art]] [[Category:Horses in literature]] [[Category:Horses in film and television]]

{{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = | width = 275
| image1 = Example-serious.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = Example of a normal image
| image2 = Example, databent.png | alt2 = | caption2 =
| footer = Databent version of the same image, employing visual artifacts }} '''Databending''' (or '''data bending''') is the process of manipulating a [[media file]] of a certain [[File format|format]], using [[software]] designed to edit files of another format. Distortions in the medium typically occur as a result, and the process either falls under a broader category of, or is frequently employed in [[glitch art]].
==Process and techniques== The term ''databending'' is derived from [[circuit bending]], in which objects such as children's toys, [[effects pedal]]s and electronic keyboards are deliberately [[short circuit]]ed by bending the [[circuit board]] to produce erratic and spontaneous sounds. Like circuit bending,<ref name="Geere2010"/> databending involves the (often unpredictable) alteration of its target's behavior. Databending achieves this alteration by manipulating the information within a media file of a certain format, using software designed to edit files of a different format; distortions in the medium typically occur as a result.<ref name="AhujaLu2014"/><ref name="Geere2010"/>
Many techniques exist, including the use of [[hex editor]]s to manipulate certain components of a [[compression algorithm]], to comparatively simple methods.<ref name="Geere2010"/> [[Michael Betancourt]] has posed a short set of instructions, included in the [[Signal Culture |''Signal Culture Cookbook,'']] that involves the direct manipulation of the digital file using a hexadecimal editing program. One such method involves the addition of audio effects through [[audio editing software]] to distort [[raw data]] interpretations of image files. Some effects produce optical analogues: adding an [[echo]] filter duplicated elements of a photo, and inversion contributed to the flipping over of an image. The similarities result from the waveforms corresponding with the layers of pixels in a [[Linear medium|linear fashion]], ordered from top to bottom.<ref name="AhujaLu2014"/> Another method, dubbed "the WordPad effect", uses the program [[WordPad]] to manipulate images through converting the raw data to the [[Rich Text Format]].<ref name="Berg2008"/>
===Categorization=== According to the artist Benjamin Berg, different techniques of the process can be grouped into three categories:<ref name="Berg2008"/> * Incorrect editing: Files of a certain format are manipulated using software designed to edit files of a different format. * Reinterpretation: Files are simply converted from one medium to another. * Forced errors: Known [[software bug]]s are exploited to force the program to terminate, usually while writing a file. The "WordPad effect" would fall under ''incorrect editing'', while ''reinterpretation'' contains a subcategory called ''sonification'', in which data other than audio is introduced simultaneously with musical audio data. The last technique is the hardest of the three to accomplish, often yielding highly unpredictable results.<ref name="Berg2008"/>
==Usage and reception== [[File:NicolaiRasterNotonLive.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Alva Noto uses sonification in his music.]] Databending is frequently employed in [[glitch art]],<ref name="AhujaLu2014"/> and is considered a sub-category of the genre.<ref name="Geere2010"/> The ''sonification'' technique is commonly used by [[glitch music]]ians such as [[Alva Noto]].<ref name="Geere2010"/> Ahuja and Lu summarized the process through a quote by Adam Clark Estes of ''[[Gizmodo]]'' as "the internet's code-heavy version of graffiti."<ref name="AhujaLu2014"/><ref name="Estes2013"/> Various groups on [[Flickr]] explore the effects of databending on imagery; an [[Internet bot]] named "GlitchBot" was created to scrape [[Creative Commons]]-licensed imagery and apply the process and upload the results.<ref name="Geere2010"/> Users on [[Vimeo]] who deal explicitly with databending and glitch art in general exist, and a [[Chicago]]-based digital art project named GLI.TC/H was funded using [[Kickstarter]] in 2011.<ref name="Weber2011"/>
== See also== * [[Compression artifact]]
==References== {{Reflist | colwidth=30em | refs=<!-- --><ref name="AhujaLu2014">{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/innovations/wp/2014/07/23/what-paris-looks-like-with-an-echo/ |title=What Paris looks like with an echo |publisher=Nash Holdings |work=The Washington Post |date=23 July 2014 |accessdate=28 July 2014 |author=Ahuja, Masuma |author2=Lu, Denise |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RPg2XURF?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/innovations/wp/2014/07/23/what-paris-looks-like-with-an-echo/ |archivedate=28 July 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> <!-- --><ref name="Berg2008">{{cite web | url=http://blog.animalswithinanimals.com/2008/08/databending-and-glitch-art-primer-part.html | title=Databending and Glitch Art Primer Part 1: The WordPad Effect | work=stAllio!'s way | date=7 August 2008 | author=Berg, Benjamin }}</ref> <!-- --><ref name="Estes2013">{{cite web |url=https://gizmodo.com/create-your-own-broken-masterpieces-with-this-glitch-ar-1309634963 |title=Create Your Own Broken Masterpieces with This Glitch Art Generator |publisher=Gawker Media |work=Gizmodo |date=13 September 2013 |accessdate=28 July 2014 |author=Estes, Adam Clark |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RPg2XURP?url=http://gizmodo.com/create-your-own-broken-masterpieces-with-this-glitch-ar-1309634963 |archivedate=28 July 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> <!-- --><ref name="Geere2010">{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2010-08/17/glitch-art-databending |title=Glitch art created by 'databending' |publisher=Condé Nast |work=Wired |date=17 August 2010 |accessdate=28 July 2014 |author=Geere, Duncan |edition=UK |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RPg2XUQy?url=http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2010-08/17/glitch-art-databending |archivedate=28 July 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> <!-- --><ref name="Weber2011">{{cite web |url=https://thenextweb.com/dd/2011/12/21/extrafile-databending-and-corrupt-files-as-art/ |title=ExtraFile: Databending and corrupt files as art |work=The Next Web |date=21 December 2011 |accessdate=28 July 2014 |author=Weber, Harrison |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RPg2XURY?url=http://thenextweb.com/dd/2011/12/21/extrafile-databending-and-corrupt-files-as-art/ |archivedate=28 July 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> }}
==External links== * [http://www.michaelbetancourt.com/pdf/Cookbook_Databending.pdf] A Simple Protocol for Databending by [[Michael Betancourt]] * [https://snorpey.github.io/jpg-glitch/ Glitch art application] by Georg Fischer * {{Flickr-inline2|photos/glitchbot/|GlitchBot}} * [http://gli.tc/ Official website] of GLI.TC/H * [http://www.hellocatfood.com/databending-using-audacity/ Databending using Audacity] by Antonio Roberts

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[Image:Derrynaflan chalice.jpg|240px|thumb|Derrynaflan Chalice]] [[Image:Derrynaflan paten.jpg|thumb|Derrynaflan Paten]]
The '''Derrynaflan Chalice''' is an 8th- or 9th-century [[Chalice (cup)|chalice]], that was found as part of the ''Derrynaflan Hoard'' of five liturgical vessels. The discovery was made on 17 February 1980 near [[Killenaule]], [[County Tipperary]] in Ireland. According to art historian Michael Ryan the hoard "represents the most complex and sumptuous expression of the ecclesiastical art-style of early-medieval Ireland as we know it in its eighth- and ninth-century maturity."<ref>Ryan 1997:997.</ref> The area known as Derrynaflan is an island of pastureland surrounded by bogland, which was the site of an early Irish [[abbey]]. The [[Chalice (cup)|chalice]] was found with a composite silver [[paten]], a hoop that may have been a stand for the paten, a liturgical [[strainer]] and a bronze basin inverted over the other objects.<ref>Michael Ryan, "The Derrynaflan Hoard and Early Irish Art" ''Speculum'' '''72'''.4 (October 1997:995–1017) p. 997, with wide-ranging notes.</ref> The group is among the most important surviving examples of [[insular art|Insular]] metalwork. It was donated to the Irish State and the items are now on display in the [[National Museum of Ireland]].<ref name="NMIweb">{{cite web |url=http://www.museum.ie/news/details_news.asp?sPressType=1&newsid=230 |title=Museum News – Press Releases (26 July 2006) – Ancient Book of Psalms Discovered |work=National Museum of Ireland Website |accessdate=16 May 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080128000927/http://www.museum.ie/news/details_news.asp?sPressType=1&newsid=230 |archivedate=28 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
The hoard was probably secreted during the turbulent 10th to 12th centuries, when Viking raids and dynastic turmoil created many occasions when valuables were hidden. The early and later 10th century is marked by a particular concentration of hoarding in Ireland.<ref>Ryan 1997:998.</ref>
==Discovery== [[File:Ireland 2010 etc 032.jpg|thumb|Detail]] Derrynaflan is a small island of dry land situated in a surrounding area of peat bogs, in the [[townland]] of Lurgoe, Co. Tipperary, northeast of [[Cashel, County Tipperary|Cashel]]. The monastery was an important foundation in the period preceding the Viking raids; the present modest ruins of a small [[Cistercians|Cistercian]] nave-and-chancel [[abbey]] church there, however, date from a later period.
The [http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/derrynaflan-hoard/ Derrynaflan Hoard] was discovered on 17 February 1980 by Michael Webb from [[Clonmel]] and his son, also Michael, while they were exploring the ancient monastic site of Derrynaflan with a metal detector.<ref>Trafficking Culture, http://traffickingculture.org/encyclopedia/case-studies/derrynaflan-hoard/</ref> They had the implied permission of the owners of the land on which the ruins stood to visit the site but they had no permission to dig on the lands. A preservation order had been made in respect of the ruin under the National Monuments Act, 1930, so that it was an offence to injure or to interfere with the site.<ref> Webb v Ireland [1988] IR 353 </ref> The discovery was initially kept secret for three weeks.<ref name=IrInd29July06>{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Our Great Discoveries | work = [[Irish Independent]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = 29 July 2006 | url = http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/our-great-discoveries-90190.html| accessdate =16 May 2008}}</ref> [[Image:Derrynaflan strainer.jpg|thumb|Derrynaflan Strainer]] [[File:Ardagh chalice.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The [[Ardagh Chalice]] was discovered in [[County Limerick]], at Reerasta Rath in Uí Fidgenti, 1868.]] The behaviour of the Webbs, and nearly seven years of litigation, culminating in the Supreme Court action where they unsuccessfully sought over £5,000,000 for the find, led to the replacement of Irish laws of [[treasure trove]] by the law in the National Monuments (Amendment) Act, 1994, with a new Section 2 being included in the legislation.
The [[Ardagh Chalice]] dates from around the same period, perhaps a century earlier, of the Derrynaflan Hoard and was found close by in neighbouring [[County Limerick]]. At the time, the ruling dynasty in Tipperary and most of [[Munster]] were the [[Eóganachta]], while their longtime allies and possible cousins the [[Uí Fidgenti]] ruled in the Limerick area. [[Feidlimid mac Cremthanin]], king-bishop of Cashel, who became [[King of Munster]] in 821 and died in 847, was a patron of the monastic foundation at Derrynaflan and has been suggested as a possible patron of the chalice.<ref>Ryan, with reservations, 1997:997: "This sort of particularism is dangerous as hypotheses of this nature tend to be elevated into 'facts'".</ref>
As a masterpiece of Insular art, the Derrynaflan chalice was included in the exhibition "The Work of Angels: Masterpieces of Celtic Metalwork, 6th–9th Centuries AD" (London, 1989, included in the catalogue).

{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox artwork | title = Fearless Girl | image = Fearless Girl sculpture by Kristen Visbal.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = The statue in March 2017 | painting_alignment = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | wikidata = Q28916452 | artist = Kristen Visbal | year = | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | catalogue = | medium = [[Bronze sculpture]] | movement = | subject = | height_metric = <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | dimensions = {{convert|50|in|cm}} tall | dimensions_ref = <ref name="Dobnik" /> | weight = {{convert|250|lb|kg}} | designation = | condition = | museum = | city = [[New York City]], New York, U.S. | coordinates = {{coord|40.705632|-74.013392|dim:1_type:landmark_region:US-NJ|display=inline,title}} | owner = [[State Street Global Advisors]] | accession = | module = | website = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> }} '''''Fearless Girl''''' is a [[bronze sculpture]] by [[Kristen Visbal]], commissioned by [[State Street Global Advisors]] (SSgA) via McCann New York. It depicts a girl who, as originally installed, faced the ''[[Charging Bull]]'' (or ''[[Wall Street]] Bull'') statue,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://adage.com/article/agency-news/things-fearless-girl/308863/ |title=Eight Things You Don't Know About 'Fearless Girl' |publisher=[[Advertising Age]]}}</ref> It was removed in November 2018 in preparation for relocation to in front of the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. A plaque with footprints was placed on the original site of ''Fearless Girl''.<ref name="Moyer">{{cite news |last=Moyer |first=Liz |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/28/fearless-girl-on-the-move-but-leaves-footprints-for-visitors.html |title='Fearless Girl' on the move, but leaves footprints for visitors to stand in her place |work=[[CNBC]] |date=2018-11-28 |accessdate=2018-11-28 }}</ref>
''Fearless Girl'' was commissioned to advertise for an [[index fund]] that comprises gender-diverse companies that have a relatively high percentage of women among their senior leadership. The plaque below the statue states: "Know the power of women in leadership. SHE makes a difference," with "SHE" being both a descriptive pronoun and the fund's [[NASDAQ]] [[ticker symbol]]. The statue was originally installed on March 7, 2017, at [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]] in the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] of [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]].
== Description == ''Fearless Girl'', which measures approximately {{convert|50|in|cm}} tall and weighs about {{convert|250|lb}},<ref name="Dobnik" /> faced ''[[Charging Bull]]'', a much larger and heavier bronze statue that is {{convert|11|ft}} tall and weighs {{convert|7100|lb}}.<ref name="Schwedel">{{cite journal |date=March 7, 2017 |title=A Bronze Little Girl Has Arrived to Face Down the Wall Street Bull. This Should Go Well. |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2017/03/07/a_bronze_little_girl_sculpture_joins_the_charging_bull_on_wall_street_to.html |journal=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |last1=Schwedel |first1=Heather |accessdate=March 7, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Dobnik" /> Both are located in [[Manhattan|Manhattan's]] [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]], at the intersection of [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] and [[Whitehall Street]].<ref name="CNN">{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/07/news/girl-statue-wall-street-bull/ |title=Why a defiant girl is staring down the Wall Street bull |date=March 7, 2017 |publisher=[[CNNMoney]] |last1=Wiener-Bronner |first1=Danielle |accessdate=March 7, 2017}}</ref>
''Fearless Girl'' is meant to "send a message" about workplace [[gender diversity]] and encourage [[Gender representation on corporate boards of directors|companies to recruit women to their boards]].<ref name="BI">{{cite news |title=A $2.5 trillion asset manager just put a statue of a defiant girl in front of the Wall Street bull |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/statue-defiant-girl-faces-wall-street-charging-bull-state-street-global-national-womens-day-2017-3 |accessdate=March 7, 2017 |work=[[Business Insider]] |date=March 7, 2017 |first1=Emma |last1=Fierberg |first2=Rachael |last2=Levy}}</ref> The plaque below the statue states: "Know the power of women in leadership. SHE makes a difference," with SHE referring to both the gender of the subject and the fund's [[NASDAQ]] [[ticker symbol]].<ref name="dutram">{{Cite news |url=http://www.nasdaq.com/article/the-fearless-girl-statue-isnt-a-symbol-it-is-an-advertisement-cm766282 |title=The 'Fearless Girl' Statue Isn't a Symbol, It Is an Advertisement |last=Dutram |first=Eric |date=March 27, 2017 |work=NASDAQ.com|access-date=March 28, 2017 |language=en-us}}</ref>
The commission by State Street Global Advisors specified that the statue should depict a girl with hands on her hips and chin up, with a height of 36 inches, which Kristen Visbal and her collaborators then increased to 50 inches, to better match the size of ''Charging Bull''.<ref name="Dobnik" /> Still, Visbal commented that "I made sure to keep her features soft; she's not defiant, she's brave, proud, and strong, not belligerent".<ref name="Dobnik" /> She modeled the sculpture on two children, but many of the distinguishing features were removed so that it would be universally appealing. A child who would represent all children "so everyone could relate to the Fearless Girl."<ref name="Dobnik" />
== History == The statue was installed on March 7, 2017—the day before [[International Women's Day]]—by [[State Street Global Advisors]], in a campaign developed by advertising agency [[McCann Erickson|McCann New York]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/nycs-fearless-girl-statue-corporate-giants-46026204 |title=Behind NYC's 'Fearless Girl' statue are 2 corporate giants |last=Dobnik |first=Verena |date=March 9, 2017 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312022256/http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/nycs-fearless-girl-statue-corporate-giants-46026204 |archivedate=March 12, 2017 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=March 13, 2017 }}</ref> SSgA was celebrating the first anniversary of its "Gender Diversity Index" fund that "invests in U.S. large-capitalization companies that rank among the highest in their sector in achieving gender diversity across senior leadership".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://blog.spdrs.com/post/driving-gender-diversity-with-a-bold-new-statement |title=Driving Gender Diversity with a Bold New Statement |last=Mavro |first=Jill |date=March 7, 2017 |website=SPDR Blog|access-date=March 28, 2017}}</ref> The concept for the statue was developed by Senior Art Director Lizzie Wilson and Senior Copywriter Tali Gumbiner. Wilson and Gumbiner established both the idea for the statue as well as the overall look of the girl using countless moodboards and imagery, which Visbal referenced.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.adweek.com/creativity/the-story-of-the-fearless-girl-from-the-women-at-mccann-who-made-her/ |title=The Story of ‘The Fearless Girl,’ From the Women at McCann Who Made Her |last=Nudd |first=Tim |date=March 10, 2017 |website=Adweek|access-date=May 4, 2017|archive-ur;=}}</ref>
''Fearless Girl'' was originally given a one-week [[New York City Hall|City Hall]] permit that was later extended to 30 days.<ref name="revesz" /> Later, it was announced that the statue would remain in place through February 2018.<ref>{{cite news |title='Fearless Girl' statue will stay through early next year |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/27/news/fearless-girl-statue-2018/ |accessdate=March 27, 2017 |publisher=CNN Money}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Silva |first1=Daniella |title='Fearless Girl' statue will face off Wall Street bull for another year |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/fearless-girl-statue-will-face-wall-street-bull-another-year-n738991 |website=NBC News |accessdate=March 27, 2017 |language=en |date=March 27, 2017}}</ref> Among those advocating for the statue to stay longer was U.S. Representative [[Carolyn Maloney]] of [[New York's 12th congressional district]], who stated, "This statue has touched hearts across the world with its symbolism of the resiliency of women."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/fearless-girl-charging-bull-wall-street-new-york-boradway-2018-bronze-statue-stand-up-a7651471.html |title=The Fearless Girl statue will stay on Wall Street until 2018 |last=O'Connor |first=Roision |date=March 27, 2017 |work=The Independent|access-date=April 11, 2017 |language=en-GB}}</ref> [[New York City Public Advocate]] [[Letitia James]] wrote a letter that supported keeping the statue, "Fearless Girl stands as a powerful beacon, showing women—young and old—that no dream is too big and no ceiling is too high".<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/manhattan/exclusive-letitia-james-fearless-girl-permanent-article-1.2996620 |title=EXCLUSIVE: Letitia James wants 'Fearless Girl' to be permanent |work=NY Daily News|access-date=April 12, 2017 |language=en}}</ref>
A petition on [[Change.org]] asking for the statue to be made permanent gathered 2,500 signatures in its first 48 hours.<ref name="revesz">{{cite news |last1=Revesz |first1=Rachel |title=Campaign launches to make 'Fearless Girl' statue on Wall Street permanent |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/fearless-girl-statue-wall-street-petition-permanent-campaign-a7621231.html |accessdate=March 10, 2017 |work=The Independent |date=March 9, 2017}}</ref><ref name="bisaria">{{cite news |last1=Bisaria |first1=Anjali |title=People Have Now Launched A Campaign To Make The 'Fearless Girl' Statue Permanent At Wall Street |url=http://www.indiatimes.com/news/world/people-have-now-launched-a-campaign-to-make-the-fearless-girl-statue-permanent-at-wall-street-273163.html |accessdate=March 10, 2017 |work=IndiaTimes |date=March 10, 2017}}</ref> Efforts to make the statue permanent continued after the statue was granted a one-year permit.<ref name="Stack">{{cite news |last1=Stack |first1=Liam |title=‘Fearless Girl’ Statue to Stay in Financial District (for Now) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/27/nyregion/fearless-girl-statue-de-blasio.html?_r=0 |accessdate=March 28, 2017 |work=The New York Times |date=March 27, 2017}}</ref> In April 2018, after ''Fearless Girl'' had been in place for thirteen months, New York City Mayor [[Bill de Blasio]] announced that both ''Charging Bull'' and ''Fearless Girl'' would be moved to a location facing the New York Stock Exchange. The move would occur before the end of 2018.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/nyregion/fearless-girl-wall-street-bull-statue-move.html |title=‘Fearless Girl’ to Move, and She May Take the Wall Street Bull With Her |last=Goodman |first=J. David |date=April 19, 2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=May 6, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name="cnn-money-move">{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2018/04/19/news/companies/fearless-girl-moving-nyse/index.html |title='Fearless Girl' is moving to a new home |last=Wiener-Bronner |first=Danielle |date=April 19, 2018 |work=CNN Money |accessdate=April 19, 2018 |publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref>
The statue was removed from its original location at Bowling Green on November 28, 2018.<ref name="Moyer"/><ref>{{cite web | title=Gone Girl: Lower Manhattan 'Fearless Girl' Statue Is 'On The Move' | website=NPR.org | date=November 28, 2018 | url=https://www.npr.org/2018/11/28/671546407/gone-girl-lower-manhattan-fearless-girl-statue-is-on-the-move | access-date=November 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title='Fearless Girl' statue moved from spot opposite bull | website=ABC7 New York | date=November 28, 2018 | url=https://abc7ny.com/4779944/ | access-date=November 1, 2018}}</ref> It will be relocated to a spot in front of the New York Stock Exchange. On the spot where the statue stood now has a marker which reads, "Fearless Girl is on the move to The New York Stock Exchange. Until she's there, stand for her." The plaque also has footprints where people can stand.<ref name="Moyer"/>
==Controversies==
=== Juxtaposition with ''Charging Bull'' === [[File:Fearless Girl (cropped).jpg|thumb|The juxtaposition of ''Fearless Girl'' and ''Charging Bull'' upset some observers, including sculptor Arturo Di Modica, who installed ''Charging Bull'' in 1989.]] [[Arturo Di Modica]], who installed ''Charging Bull'' in 1989, asked that the statue of the girl be removed, arguing that the piece exploited his work for commercial purposes and altered the perception of the bull.<ref name="Mettler">{{cite news |last1=Mettler |first1=Katie |title=Charging Bull sculptor says Fearless Girl distorts his art, so he's fighting back |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-charging-bull-sculptor-fearless-girl-20170412-story.html |work=Chicago Tribune |date=April 12, 2017}}</ref> He called ''Fearless Girl'' "an advertising trick" that he wants relocated, citing its political messaging.<ref name="Stack2">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/27/nyregion/fearless-girl-statue-de-blasio.html?_r=0 |title=‘Fearless Girl’ Statue to Stay in Financial District (for Now) |date=March 27, 2017 |work=The New York Times |last1=Stack |first1=Liam |accessdate=March 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Dobnik">{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/03/26/new-york-invite-fearless-girl-statue-stay-wall-street/99677644/ |title=Will New York invite the 'Fearless Girl' statue to stay on Wall Street? |date=March 26, 2017 |work=USA Today |language=en |last1=Dobnik |first1=Verena |accessdate=March 27, 2017}}</ref>
On April 12, 2017, Di Modica and his attorney, former [[New York Civil Liberties Union]] director [[Norman Siegel]], challenged city officials who let the ''Fearless Girl'' statue be installed.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/apr/12/charging-bull-new-york-fearless-girl-statue-copyright-claim |title='Charging Bull' sculptor says New York's 'Fearless Girl' statue violates his rights |date=April 11, 2017 |work=The Guardian|access-date=April 13, 2017 |publisher=Associated Press |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/12/nyregion/charging-bull-sculpture-wall-street-fearless-girl.html |title=Wounded by ‘Fearless Girl,’ Creator of ‘Charging Bull’ Wants Her to Move |last=Barron |first=James |date=April 12, 2017 |work=The New York Times|access-date=April 13, 2017 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Di Modica said that the statue corrupted ''Charging Bull''{{'s}} artistic integrity by distorting the intent of his statue from "a symbol of prosperity and for strength" into a villain, and does so for SSgA's commercial gain.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/04/12/charging-bull-sculptor-says-fearless-girl-distorts-his-art-hes-fighting-back/ |title=‘Charging Bull’ sculptor says ‘Fearless Girl’ distorts his art. He’s fighting back. |website=Washington Post|access-date=April 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/12/523592057/sculptor-of-wall-street-bull-says-fearless-girl-horns-in-on-his-work |title=Sculptor Of Wall Street Bull Says 'Fearless Girl' Horns In On His Work |website=NPR|access-date=April 12, 2017}}</ref> Siegel said a lawsuit had not been filed as of yet.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> De Blasio supported keeping the statue, tweeting that "Men who don't like women taking up space are exactly why we need the Fearless Girl."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Smith |first1=Aaron |title=NYC mayor to 'Charging Bull' artist: 'Fearless Girl is staying put.' |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/04/12/news/charging-bull-fearless-girl/ |work=CNNMoney |date=April 12, 2017}}</ref>
Some women criticized the statue as "corporate feminism" that violated their own [[feminism|feminist]] principles.<ref>[http://hyperallergic.com/364474/the-sculpture-of-a-fearless-girl-on-wall-street-is-fake-corporate-feminism/ The Sculpture of a “Fearless Girl” on Wall Street Is Fake Corporate Feminism. The bronze statue installed by an advertising firm and a financial firm represents basically everything that’s wrong with our society.] Jillian Steinhauer, Hyperallergic, March 10, 2017</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/mar/14/fearless-girl-statue-whats-wrong-feminism-today The 'Fearless Girl' statue sums up what's wrong with feminism today. Corporate feminism always ends up betraying women’s struggle for justice. That’s why this Wall Street-funded sculpture will never be a symbol to embrace.] Cara Marsh Sheffler. The Guardian. March 14, 2017</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' columnist Gina Bellafante called it "an exercise in corporate imaging" by State Street, which, she wrote, had entered into a [[deferred prosecution]] agreement with the [[United States Department of Justice]], agreeing to pay more than $64 million to resolve fraud charges for secretly billing clients for unwarranted commissions. "Corporate feminism", she wrote, "operates with the singular goal of aiding and abetting a universe of mothers who tuck their daughters in at night whispering, 'Someday, honey, you can lead the [[emerging markets]] and [[sovereign debt]] team at [[Citigroup]], and then become a director at [[Yahoo!|Yahoo]].{{'"}}<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/16/nyregion/fearless-girl-statue-manhattan.html |title=The False Feminism of ‘Fearless Girl’ |last=Bellafante |first=Ginia |date=March 16, 2017 |work=The New York Times|access-date=April 13, 2017 |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Christine Emba, an opinion writer for ''[[The Washington Post]]'', wrote that the statue "portrays the empowered woman as a child, reinforcing the idea of femaleness as cute and inoffensive—a child with potential, maybe, but not all the way there."<ref>{{cite web |last=Emba |first=Christine |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/fearless-girl-and-charging-bull-are-more-alike-than-youd-think/2017/04/14/d3d909de-2147-11e7-ad74-3a742a6e93a7_story.html |title='Fearless Girl' and 'Charging Bull' are more alike than you'd think |date=April 14, 2017 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=April 15, 2017}}</ref>
=== Other controversies === [[Gothamist]] reported on March 20, 2017, that masked New York activists covered the statue in "[[Make America Great Again]]" apparel and a [[flag of the United States|US flag]]. They also placed pro-[[Donald Trump]] signs on it, including one reading "VETS B4 ILLEGALS" and another with a drawing of [[Pepe the Frog]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://gothamist.com/2017/03/20/fearless_girl_statue_trumped.php#photo-1 |title=Men In MAGA Hats Transform 'Fearless Girl' Statue Into Trump Supporter |work=Gothamist|access-date=November 1, 2017 |language=en-US}}</ref>
On May 29, 2017, artist Alex Gardega added a statue of a small dog, titled ''Pissing Pug'' (alternatively ''Peeing Pug''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/05/30/news/fearless-girl-urinating-dog/ |title='Fearless Girl' joined briefly by 'Peeing Pug' statue |date=May 30, 2017 |work=[[CNNMoney]]}}</ref> or ''Sketchy Dog''), and removed it after approximately three hours.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/urinating-sketchy-dog-statue-appears-next-fearless-girl-n766071 |title=Urinating dog statue placed next to "Fearless Girl" as a critique |publisher=[[NBC News]]}}</ref> He described ''Fearless Girl'' as "corporate nonsense" and "disrespect to the artist that made the bull."<ref name="2017-05-29 NYP">{{cite news |last1=Fugallo |first1=Nick |last2=Jaeger |first2=Max |date=May 29, 2017 |title=Pissed-off artist adds statue of urinating dog next to 'Fearless Girl' |url=https://nypost.com/2017/05/29/pissed-off-artist-adds-statue-of-urinating-dog-next-to-fearless-girl/ |dead-url=no |work=[[New York Post]] |publisher=Jesse Angelo |issn=1090-3321 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180624063905/https://nypost.com/2017/05/29/pissed-off-artist-adds-statue-of-urinating-dog-next-to-fearless-girl/ |archive-date=June 24, 2018 |access-date=July 19, 2018}}</ref>
On October 6, 2017, State Street, the company that funded ''Fearless Girl'', paid $5 million to settle a lawsuit from its female and minority employees who alleged the company violated equal pay rights.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/06/business/fearless-girl-settlement.html |title=Firm Behind ‘Fearless Girl’ Statue Underpaid Women, U.S. Says |work=The New York Times |date=October 6, 2017 |access-date=August 8, 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
== Effects == As reported by [[Bloomberg News]], analysts from marketing firm Apex Marketing estimated that the statue resulted in $7.4 million in free publicity for SSGA as of April 2017, broken down into $201,075 worth of free radio coverage, $393,047 worth of free social media coverage, $3,115,751 worth of free TV coverage, and $3,729,926 worth of free online/print news coverage.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-28/fearless-girl-earns-7-4-million-in-free-media-for-state-street |title=The Fearless Girl Is Worth $7.4 Million in Free Publicity for This Company |date=April 28, 2017 |work=Bloomberg.com |access-date=June 1, 2017}}</ref>
At the 2017 [[Cannes Lions]] festival, ''Fearless Girl'' won three Grand Prix on the first day of the event alone, in the Glass (which deals with marketing addressing gender inequality) and PR categories, and tying for first in the Outdoor category alongside a campaign by [[Twitter]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.adweek.com/creativity/fearless-girl-takes-cannes-by-storm-winning-3-grand-prix-on-her-first-day/ |title=Fearless Girl Takes Cannes by Storm, Winning 3 Grand Prix on Her First Day |work=Adweek |access-date=June 22, 2017 |language=en-US}}</ref>
== Duplicates == A duplicate of the sculpture was unveiled outside the [[Grand Hotel (Oslo)|Grand Hotel]] in the Norwegian city of [[Oslo]] on March 8, 2018. It faces the Norwegian [[parliament]] [[Storting]]et.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.aftenposten.no/osloby/i/kayG3a/Skapte-spetakkel-pa-Wall-Street---na-star-Fearless-girl-pa-Karl-Johan |title=Skapte spetakkel på Wall Street - nå står «Fearless girl» på Karl Johan |work=Aftenposten|access-date=March 8, 2018 |language=nb-NO |quote=there is a duplicate that has now come to Oslo.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.tv2.no/a/9726322/ |title=Norge har fått sin egen «Fearless Girl» |work=TV 2|access-date=March 8, 2018 |language=no-nb |quote=A duplicate of the world-renowned statue is unveiled}}</ref>
==Awards== * The Most Next Award, 2018 [[Association of Independent Commercial Producers]] (AICP) Next Awards<ref>{{cite news |last=Staff |first=Writer |url=https://www.shootonline.com/news/fearless-girl%C2%A0earns-best-show-most%C2%A0distinction-aicp-next-awards |title="Fearless Girl" Earns Best in Show "Most" Distinction At AICP Next Awards |work=Shoot.com |publisher=DCA Business Media LLC |date=June 12, 2018 |accessdate=June 20, 2018}}</ref> * Grand Effie – best in show, North American [[Effie Award]]s<ref>{{cite news |last=Sherwood |first=I-Hsien |url=http://adage.com/article/agency-news/fearless-girl-takes-top-honor-2018-effie-awards/313709/ |title='Fearless Girl' Takes Top Honor at 2018 EFFIE Awards |work=[[Advertising Age]] |date=May 31, 2018 |accessdate=June 20, 2018}}</ref> * Fearless Girl won 18 Cannes Lions at the 2017 Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity:<ref>{{cite news |last=Griner |first=David |url=https://www.adweek.com/creativity/fearless-girls-dominating-run-at-cannes-ends-with-4-grand-prix-and-18-total-lions/ |title=Fearless Girl’s Dominating Run at Cannes Ends With 4 Grand Prix and 18 Total Lions |work=[[Adweek]] |date=2017-06-24 |accessdate=2018-10-17 }}</ref> ** Titanium: Grand Prix ** Outdoor: Grand Prix, one gold ** PR: Grand Prix, one gold, one silver ** Glass: Grand Prix ** Promo & Activation: Two golds, one silver ** Media: Two golds ** Direct: Two golds, one silver, one bronze ** Design: Two golds Fearless Girl is one of only two campaigns that have ever won four Grand Prix at Cannes.
==See also== {{Portal|New York City|Visual arts}} * [[2017 in art]] * [[Day Without a Woman]], a protest held on March 8, 2017 * [[Women in business]]

{{more citations needed|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Fred Segal | logo = Fred Segal Logo 2015.jpg | type = | industry = Lifestyle, Retail | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | foundation = 1961 | key_people = * [[Allison Samek]] {{small|(CEO)}} * [[John Frierson]] {{small|(President)}} | location = Los Angeles, California, U.S.; [[Daikanyamachō, Shibuya|Tokyo]] and [[Kobe]], Japan | locations = 9 | homepage = {{URL|www.fredsegal.com}} }}
'''Fred Segal''' is a clothing and accessories [[retail]] store founded in [[West Hollywood, California]]. Its flagship store is on [[Sunset Boulevard]] in West Hollywood.
==Stores== There are currently three Fred Segal locations in the United States. The new global flagship is in West Hollywood, the historic Fred Segal location is on Melrose and the third location is at [[LAX]]’s Thomas Bradley International Terminal. There are two international flagships in Japan, one in the Daikanyama neighborhood of Tokyo and the other in Kobe. In September 2018, Fred Segal stores opened in Switzerland (3 stores), Taipei, and Kuala Lumpur. <ref>[https://wwd.com/business-news/retail/fred-segal-ramps-international-store-growth-plans-1202773128/]</ref>
== History == Over five decades ago, Fred Segal opened a local [[jeans]]-only store. This 300-square-foot store grew over the years, and with the expansion, Segal invited key managers to purchase and run select boutiques within their respective area of merchandising expertise within the Fred Segal center offering them to participate as franchisees under the Fred Segal Brand. These franchisees brought in the style and merchandise that eventually know collectively as "Fred Segal."
In May 2012, the worldwide licensing rights to the brand were acquired by SANDOW, a company with brands spanning the design, fashion and beauty sectors.<ref>[http://www.wwd.com/retail-news/specialty-stores/fred-segals-new-deal-5889483 Fred Segal's new deal] [[Women's Wear Daily]]</ref> In late 2012, SANDOW announced Fred Segal's expansion strategy to open new flagship locations, both internationally and domestically, launch Fred Segal’s first [[e-commerce]] site, and create private merchandise lines.
In May 2014, SANDOW and Fred Segal announced the partnership with equity investor Evolution Media Partners (Evolution), a joint venture between Evolution Media Capital (EMC), an entertainment, media and sports merchant bank formed in partnership with [[Creative Artists Agency]] (CAA); TPG Growth, the middle market and growth equity investment platform of global investment firm TPG; and Participant Media, the global entertainment company founded in 2004 by [[Jeff Skoll]].
In September 2017, Fred Segal opened their domestic flagship store on the corner of Sunset and La Cienega in West Hollywood, CA.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fred-segal-flagship-opening-la-week-1042852 |title=Inside the New Fred Segal Flagship Opening in L.A. This Week |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}</ref>
== In popular culture == {{in popular culture|date=September 2017}} * In the 1987 movie ''Maid To Order'', Ally Sheedy's spoiled Beverly Hills Brat character Jessie Montgomery mentions shopping at Fred Segal. * In ''[[Clueless (film)|Clueless]]'', Cher asks her maid when trying to put together an [[outfit]] for her drivers license test, "Lucy! Where's my white collarless shirt from Fred ''Segal?!''" * It is in ''[[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]]'' Episode 1, Season 1 "The Pilot," the first scene takes place in Fred Segal Melrose. * It is mentioned as a meeting point for "Stupid Girls" in the [[Stupid Girls|2006 single]] by [[Pink (singer)|Pink]]. * In [[Bret Easton Ellis]]'s ''[[Less Than Zero (novel)|Less Than Zero]]'', Fred Segal is mentioned several times. Clay, the protagonist, thinks that all English boys he meets work at Fred Segal. * In ''[[Legally Blonde]]'', Elle Woods, played by [[Reese Witherspoon]], relates the following story to her new classmates at [[Harvard]]: "Oh, Two Weeks ago, I saw [[Cameron Diaz]] at Fred Segal, and I talked her out of buying this truly heinous angora sweater. Whoever said [[Orange (colour)|orange]] was the new [[pink]] was seriously disturbed!" * In ''[[White Oleander]]'', Fred Segal is one of the many Hollywood stores that Claire Richards takes Astrid Magnussen to for clothing. * In ''[[The Game: Penetrating the Secret Society of Pickup Artists|The Game]]'', where Neil Strauss, the author, buys his first set of hip clothes. * In ''[[The L Word]]'' during a flashback, Alice sees Dana in the Fred Segal cafe, which she uses as evidence Dana is gay, as it is "The biggest lezzy hangout in LA". It's also mentioned while Shane is doing work for Veronica Bloom "...Fred Segal haircut". * In ''[[Secrets of My Hollywood Life]]'' by [[Jen Calonita]], Kaitlin Burke, a famous star, claims that her favorite store is Fred Segal. * In ''[[The Closer]]'', Chief Brenda Leigh Johnson mentions that Sergeant Gabriel "likes his suits from Fred Segal", a fact which is noted by the medical examiner in a later episode. * In "Cracker Ass Fantastic" by [[Dirt Nasty]], he raps "Have you ever been to Fred Segal's?" * In Zoey Deans' books like the A-List & Talent * In ''[[The O.C.]]'' Season 3, Episode 8, "The Game Plan", Summer is looking at [[Brown University]] and Taylor says, "I hear the Ivys often recruit from Fred Segal." * In ''[[Beverly Hills, 90210]]'' Season 1, Episode 19, "April Is The Cruelest Month", Brenda finds Donna shopping there. * In the song "Ka-Blamo!" by [[The Lonely Island]], Fred Segal is mentioned in the lyrics: "You met Fred Segal at a debutante's ball!"<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qn7duAZjP8w YouTube]</ref> * In the movie ''[[Boiler Room (film)|Boiler Room]]'' the character Jim Young played by Ben Affleck makes mention of his Fred Segal necktie while speaking to trainees about how to pitch stocks effectively * On "[[Dawson's Creek]]", Season 5 Episode 23, Audrey ([[Busy Philipps]]) tries to persuade Joey ([[Katie Holmes]]) to go to Los Angeles, saying, "There's always Fred Segal." She goes on to describe it as "heaven on Earth."

{{Infobox play | name = Frozen | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | writer = Bryony Lavery | chorus = | characters = {{Unbulleted list| Agnetha | Ingrid | Guard | Nancy | Ralph | Voice of David Nabkus }} | mute = | setting = Present-day [[England]] | premiere = {{Start date|1998|5|1|df=y}} | place = [[Birmingham Repertory Theatre]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = | web = }}
'''''Frozen''''' is a play by [[Bryony Lavery]] that tells the story of the disappearance of a 10-year-old girl, Rhona. The play follows Rhona's mother and killer over the years that follow. They are linked by a doctor who is studying what causes men to commit such crimes. The themes of the play include emotional paralysis and forgiveness.
==Productions== The play was first performed at [[Birmingham Repertory Theatre]] in 1998 and won the Best New Play Award from the Theatrical Management Association.<ref>{{cite news|author=Kate Kellaway |url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2002/jun/23/features.review27 |title=Interview with Bryony Lavery, author of Frozen | From the Observer | The Observer |publisher=Guardian |date= June 23, 2002|accessdate=2011-10-27 |location=London}}</ref> It later made its debut at the Royal National Theatre's Cottesloe Theatre on 3 July 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/8213/past-events/past-productions-20012003.html |title=Past productions 2001-2003 - Past Events |publisher=National Theatre |date= |accessdate=2011-10-27}}</ref>
The play was revived at The [[Theatre Royal Haymarket]] starring [[Jason Watkins (actor)|Jason Watkins]], [[Suranne Jones]] and [[Nina Sosanya]] for a strictly limited season from February 2018.<ref>http://www.trh.co.uk/whatson/frozen/</ref>
''Frozen'' opened [[Off-Broadway]] in February 2004 at the Manhattan Class Company Theatre starring [[Swoosie Kurtz]], [[Brian F. O'Byrne]] and [[Laila Robins]]. It transferred to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in May and closed in August 2004.<ref name=talkin>[http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/sfla/sfla52.html "Talkin' Broadway Regional News & Reviews - "Frozen" in Southern Florida"] talkinbroadway.com, October 24, 2004</ref> ''Frozen'' was nominated for a [[Tony Award for Best Play]] in 2004, and earned a [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actor in a Play]] (Brian F. O'Byrne).
==Plot and characters== The story is set in present-day [[England]] and involves three main characters: a [[serial killer]] named Ralph, who kidnaps and murders a young girl; the murdered girl's mother, Nancy; a New York [[psychiatrist]], Agnetha, who travels to England to examine Ralph. The three lives slowly intersect — and the characters gradually change and become "unfrozen" as they come to terms with the idea of forgiveness.
The script begins in [[monologue]]s, each person showing his or her side of the story; the audience sees each person's story intertwine as they connect with one another.
==Allegations of plagiarism== In September 2004, papers around the world (including ''[[The Times (London)|The Times]]'', ''[[The Observer]]'', the ''[[New York Times]]'', and the [[Associated Press]]) reported that Lavery had allegedly [[plagiarism|plagiarized]] significant portions (nearly 675 words) of the play from a 1997 ''[[The New Yorker]]'' article by [[Malcolm Gladwell]] about psychiatrist [[Dorothy Otnow Lewis|Dorothy Lewis]], and from Lewis' own 1998 book ''Guilty by Reason of Insanity.''
Lewis claimed that ''Frozen'' was based in large part on her life and that the play lifted both themes and verbatim passages from both sources. However, after interviewing Lavery, Gladwell wrote a second ''New Yorker'' article in which he characterized Lavery’s appropriation as "permissible borrowing." Lavery, for her part, acknowledged that all three characters were drawn heavily from external sources. For the character of Ralph, she drew on the book ''[[The Murder of Childhood]]'' by Ray Wyre and Tim Tate. For the character of Nancy, she drew on an article in ''[[The Guardian]]'' by Marian Partington, whose sister Lucy had been murdered by the serial killers [[Fred West|Fred and Rosemary West]]. And, for the character of Agnetha, Lavery drew on the Gladwell article. "I wanted [the play] to be accurate", she told Gladwell.<ref>[http://gladwell.com/something-borrowed/ Gladwell - Something Borrowed] Nov 2004</ref>
==Reviews== *"[A] big, brave, compassionate play about [[grief]], revenge, forgiveness and bearing the unbearable." -- ''[[The Guardian]]''
The ''TalkinBroadway'' reviewer of a Florida production wrote: "[A] powerful drama ... about three people living the human condition... a story that needs to continue to be told."<ref name=talkin/>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Malcolm Gladwell, [http://gladwell.com/damaged/ ""Damaged""], ''[[The New Yorker]]'', February 24, 1997 *[http://www.redorbit.com/news/general/88801/playwright_lavery_accused_of_plagiarism/index.html Tony-nominated playwright Bryony Lavery accused of plagiarism], [[Associated Press]], September 25, 2004 *[[Jesse McKinley]], [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F05E6DE1F39F936A1575AC0A9629C8B63 ''Playwright Created a Psychiatrist By Plagiarizing One, Accusers Say''], ''[[New York Times]]'', September 25, 2004, Page B-1 *Malcolm Gladwell, [https://web.archive.org/web/20130114152902/http://www.gladwell.com/2004/2004_11_25_a_borrowed.html ''Something Borrowed: Should a charge of plagiarism ruin your life?''], ''[[The New Yorker]]'', November 22, 2004

{{Unreferenced|date=September 2008}} [[File:The sun set of GOLDEN MILE.jpg|thumb|right|300px|View of the Golden Mile at sunset]] [[File:Golden_Mile_in_Durban.jpeg|thumb|right|300px|View of Golden Mile from North Beach]] [[Image:GoldenMileDurbanduringJulyFest2004.jpg|thumb|right|300px|View of the Golden Mile, from the Snake Park to Harbour Mouth]]
The '''Golden Mile''' (or, colloquially, "The Mile") is the popular stretch of [[beach]]front in the city of [[Durban]], [[KwaZulu-Natal]], [[South Africa]], including the [[promenade]] that runs along with it. It runs roughly from uShaka Beach (where the [[uShaka Marine World]] is located) in [[Point Waterfront]] to [[Suncoast Casino and Entertainment World]] in the north and now includes a route directly to Moses Mabhida Stadium. It abuts the central business district of the city to its west.
It is one of the main tourist attractions in the Durban area. The wide stretch of golden sands, artificially separated by various [[piers]], provides excellent opportunities for sun-worshippers and swimmers to enjoy the sub-tropical sunshine and warm waters of the [[Indian Ocean]]. Most of the Mile's beaches are protected year-round by [[lifeguards]] and [[shark]] nets. The Mile is also a well-known [[surfing|surfer's]] haven. The South Beach end, in particular, is well known as a safe beach for neophyte surfers. The beachfront properties are a mix of residential [[apartments]] and tourist [[hotels]], development of which boomed in the 1970s, although remnants of Durban's [[art-deco]] architecture are still evident. Interspersed among the beachfront properties are several popular restaurants and nightclubs.
The Golden Mile has long been a popular [[domestic holiday]] destination and during the holiday seasons (June–July and December–January) South Africans from across the country, but in particular the [[Gauteng]] region, flock to enjoy its many attractions, which include:
*[[Blue Lagoon (Durban)|Blue Lagoon]], a popular hangout, picnic and fishing spot *''Mini Town'' with a miniature replica of Durban, complete with a working miniature railway and airport. *[[Moses Mabhida Stadium]] *Traditional market vendors and other hawkers with a selection of [[Zulu people|Zulu]] art and crafts. *An [[oceanway]] pavement along the beaches to encourage more people to enjoy walking and cycling. *[[Suncoast Casino and Entertainment World]], a casino complex with a semi-private beach, restaurants, shops and public entertainment facilities. *[[uShaka Marine World]] aquarium, water park, dolphinarium, containing a restaurant with the largest shark tank in the world. *[[North Beach (Durban)|North Beach]], [[Dairy Beach]], the [[Bay of Plenty (Durban)|Bay of Plenty]], Snake Park, Pirates and Country Club beaches are popular [[surfing]] beaches separated by the piers. *The Skate Park in front of the Bay of Plenty caters for skateboarders, roller bladers and BMX'ers. *The Surfing Museum, a historical site cataloguing some of Durban's surfing history.

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Hillsboro Artists' Regional Theatre |image = HART logo.gif |size = 100px |abbreviation = HART |formation = 1994 |type = Non-profit [[community theatre]] |purpose = [[Theatre|Theatrical productions]] |location = [[Hillsboro, Oregon]]
{{coord|45|31|17|N|122|59|17|W|region:US-OR|display=inline,title}} |region_served = |membership = |leader_title = President of the Board |leader_name = Doug Sellers |key_people = Aaron Morrow (Senior Artistic Director), Sarah Ominski (Artistic Director) |main_organ =Board of Directors |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.hart-theatre.org www.hart-theatre.org] |board_of_directors=Lawrence Whitlock, Mike Irwin, Marlys Carter, Alice Dalrymple, April Felder, Evan Hale, Paul Johnson, Stacie Loose, Bob Morrison, Michael Rouches}} '''Hillsboro Artists' Regional Theatre''' (HART), originally the '''Hillsboro Actors Repertory Theater''', is a [[community theatre]] group in [[Hillsboro, Oregon|Hillsboro]], [[Oregon]], United States. Founded in 1994, the non-profit group presents around six plays each year. Their 99-seat [[theater]] is located in downtown Hillsboro next to the [[Hillsboro Civic Center]] along Washington Street. ==History== The Hillsboro Actors Repertory Theater was founded in 1994 by John and Kim Sandstrom as an extension of their dinner-theater company SandStorm Productions.{{cite news|title=You gotta have HART|last=Colby|first=Richard N.|date=August 26, 1994|work=The Oregonian|page=D2}} The married couple opened the theater in the former [[J. C. Penney]] store in downtown Hillsboro using their own money, grants, and donated time a materials. Kim Sandstrom also started the Hillsboro Actors Training studio at the same time. HART’s debut production was the comedy ''Light Up the Sky'' written by playwright [[Moss Hart]].{{cite news|title=Hillsboro theater company debuts with Moss Hart’s ‘Light up the Sky’|last=Wood|first=Mark Dundas|date=September 8, 1994 |work=The Oregonian |page=D8}} Directed by Nicholette Reid, the production debuted in September 1994. By the end of their second season in 1996, the 70-seat theater had produced 11 plays.{{cite news|title=Success writes a happy script for Actors Repertory Theater|last=Colby|first=Richard N.|date=February 27, 1996|work=The Oregonian|page=B2}} Productions in the early years included ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', ''[[Barefoot in the Park]]'', and ''[[Show Boat]]'' among others. In February 1996, the Sandstroms began looking at selling the company to a non-profit group. They sold it that year to the Friends of HART in order to focus on raising their family, though Kim remained involved as artistic director for a year.{{cite news|title=West Zoner: Staging real life|last=Mandel|first=Michelle|date=August 14, 2003|work=The Oregonian|page=1}} Kim Sandstrom took a hiatus from performing in 2001 after developing health problems, but returned in 2003 to start in ''[[Shirley Valentine]]'', a one-person play by [[Willy Russell]]. Actor [[Bret Harrison]] got his first acting role at HART in a production of ''[[Our Town]]'' in these early years of HART. By 2004, Michael Hibbard had become the artistic director at HART and in June the company had to move out of its original home that held 83 seats after rent doubled at the space.{{cite news|title=West Zoner: The last curtain call|last=Smith|first=Jill|date=June 3, 2004|work=The Oregonian|page=1}} The group had also changed its name to Hillsboro Artists' Regional Theatre. Productions were then held and a variety of venues, including the [[Glenn & Viola Walters Cultural Arts Center]]. [[File:HART Theatre night - Hillsboro, Oregon.JPG|thumb|HART Theatre entrance]] In February 2005, the theater company began negotiating with the city of Hillsboro to lease a building next to the new [[Hillsboro Civic Center]].{{cite news|title=West Zoner: Deal sets stage for theater to have home|last=Danks|first=Holly |date=February 3, 2005|work=The Oregonian|page=1}} HART needed to raise more than $350,000 before late October to remodel the location along southeast Washington Street that previously housed a [[Pizza Schmizza]] restaurant and an office of [[Portland General Electric]]. Later the city gave an extension on the time HART had to raise the $600,000 needed to remodel the building.{{cite news|title=Metro West Neighbors; Hillsboro theater's fundraiser extended|last=Bermudez|first=Esmeralda|date=October 20, 2005|work=The Oregonian|page=1}} In December 2005, the theater received a $60,000 grant from the state of Oregon.{{cite news|title=Hillsboro theater gets early holiday present|date=December 23, 2005|work=The Oregonian|page=C3}} Major contributors to the fundraising campaign included [[Spirit Mountain Casino (Oregon)|Spirit Mountain Foundation]], the [[Collins Foundation]], and the [[Meyer Memorial Trust]] who had the largest donation with $100,000.{{cite news|title=Metro West Neighbors; Hillsboro Artists' theater closes in on funds goal|last=Gregory|first=Roger|date=May 18, 2006|work=The Oregonian|page=7}} By December 2006, the group had raised enough funds to sign a ten-year lease on the city-owned building at Second and Washington.{{cite news|title=Metro West Neighbors; Group hopes to perform in new theater in March|last=Bermudez|first=Esmeralda|date=December 28, 2006|work=The Oregonian|page=4}} The new theater opened in April 2007 with [[Marc Camoletti (playwright)|Marc Camoletti]]’s ''[[Don't Dress for Dinner]]''.{{cite news|title=Metro West Neighbors; Hillsboro Will arts help revive downtown?|last=Gorman|first=Kathleen|date=March 29, 2007|work=The Oregonian|page=13}} In September 2009, the theater added a $15,000 marquee to the building.{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/washingtoncounty/index.ssf/2009/09/hillsboros_hart_theater_looks.html|title=Hillsboro's HART theater looks ahead on 15th anniversary|last=Pate|first=Karen|date=September 17, 2009|work=The Oregonian|accessdate=2009-09-23}} More recent productions have included ''[[Quilters]]'' in 2010,{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/living/argus/index.ssf?/base/lifestyle/1271445719256810.xml&coll=6|title=Quilters HART presents the musical with quilts loaned by the Westside Quilters Guild|first=JoAnn|last=Boatwright|date=April 16, 2010|work=The Hillsboro Argus|accessdate=2012-09-29}} ''[[Woman In Black]]'' in 2011,{{cite News-Times|accessdate=2012-09-29}} and ''[[Gracie for President]]'' in 2012.{{cite news|url=http://washingtoncountyreview.blogspot.com/2012/09/gracie-for-president-at-hart.html|title=HART Theatre keeps "the memories of early show business greats alive"|last=Arth|first=Tina|date=September 12, 2012|work=Washington County Review|accessdate=2012-09-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121129055436/http://washingtoncountyreview.blogspot.com/2012/09/gracie-for-president-at-hart.html|archivedate=November 29, alive"|last=Baker|first=Darrell|date=September 12, 2012|work=Washington County Review|accessdate=2012-09-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121129055436/http://washingtoncountyreview.blogspot.com/2012/09/gracie-for-president-at-hart.html|archivedate=November 29, 2012|df=}} The theatre offers new works as well as the familiar, making an ongoing commitment to their patrons, local playwrights, directors and actors to bring a variety of entertainment and performances to the local community.{{cite news|url=http://www.hart-theatre.org/from-the-board-president|title=From the Board President|date=April 6, 2012|first=Batya|last=Podos|work=HART website|accessdate=2012-09-29|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328042621/http://www.hart-theatre.org/from-the-board-president/|archivedate=March 28, 2014|df=}} ==Productions== Hillsboro Artists' Regional Theatre produces six to ten shows each year.{{cite news|title=West Zoner: Think theatrically, act locally|last=Mandel|first=Michelle|date=November 27, 2003|work=The Oregonian|page=18}} The theater is a [[community theater]], and thus actors are unpaid. Those actors involved in productions often perform other roles with the theater including making costumes, cleaning, and other behind the scenes work. Shows are held on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays, with Sunday shows as [[wikt:matinée|matinées]].[http://www.hart-theatre.org/productions.html Productions.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225143548/http://www.hart-theatre.org/productions.html |date=2010-02-25 }} HART Theatre. Retrieved on September 11, 2009. The theater is housed in a {{convert|3825|ft2|adj=on}} building owned by Hillsboro. Seating 99 people, the building includes a concession stand, a lobby, a ticket office, dressing rooms, restrooms, and a {{convert|800|ft2|adj=on}} stage. ==See also== *[[Bag & Baggage Productions]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.forestgrovenewstimes.com/news/story.php?story_id=123921493354038800 Hillsboro theatre’s ‘Bleacher Bums’ delves into pro baseball history – comedically] *[http://www.beavertonvalleytimes.com/features/story.php?story_id=116371215935700000 Beaverton mom helps bring theater to local families] {{Hillsboro Oregon}} [[Category:Community theatre]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Oregon]] [[Category:Regional theatre in the United States]] [[Category:Theatre companies in Oregon]] [[Category:Culture of Hillsboro, Oregon]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Hillsboro, Oregon]]
